I agree, "Jap" is a very insensitive, unkind, and uneducated way to describe a Japanese person. It's commonly used to express disrespectfulness, hatefulness or displeasure towards a person because he/she is a Japanese. It was obviously spelled out on the photo itself, and you weren't pressed for space, so was it necessary to abbreviate like so? If you insist on abbreviating, please use the internationally accepted abbreviation, "JP", or presenting the complete spelling. also here:

Jap 2. JAP Main Entry: Jap Listen to the pronunciation of Jap Pronunciation: \ˈjap\ Function: noun or adjective Date: 1886 usually disparaging : japanese

Thanks for understanding that no offense is intended. We retain the original title of a photograph as part of preserving the historical record. The Bain News Service photo titles are available from several sources—typed in the set of caption cards consulted while making the scans, hand-written on an older set of cards, and etched on the negatives themselves. Abbreviated spellings are common in each source, but, in this case, the sources differ. Transcribing the fuller title directly from the negative provides more information, and that source is now used.

Nathan Straus ran several "milk depots" around New York to provide "sterilized" (pasteurized) milk at one cent per glass, a fee that was intended to be charitable without making people feel that they were receiving charity. The City Hall Park depot opened in 1894. Up until that time, many infants died from contaminated milk, especially in the poorer sections of New York during the summer months. The availability of affordable safe milk saved many lives. Ref: www.realmilk.com/untoldstory_1.html

"The Amerika, the largest ship in the world, is 687 feet long, 74 feet 6 inches wide, and 53 feet deep. She can carry about 4,000 passengers and crew." (Hamburg-American Steamship Line) – NY Times reporting on maiden voyage, October 11, 1905. "USS America (ID # 3006), 1917-1919. Originally the German passenger liner Amerika (1905-1917). Later the U.S. Army Transport America (1919-1920), the U.S.passenger liner America (1921-1940) and the U.S. Army Transport Edmund B. Alexander (1940-1957)" – Dept of the Navy
I concur - according to references by Arnold Kludas, she was originally the German Amerika, and after being seized by the US upon declaration of war with Germany, was renamed the America.
Is there some irony there?

She also was, in 1913, no longer the largest ship in the world -- the Imperator was, which probably explains all the pictures of its maiden voyage to NYC and the juxtaposition of this picture with it.

From en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Six_Times_Square, Six Times Square, also known as the Newsweek Building or Knickerbocker Building, is a building located at 1466 Broadway at the southeast corner of 42nd Street in New York City. This is definitely the Longacre Bldg. , showing 42nd St. in the foreground. Across 42nd street is the Hotel Knickerbocker. In the left background is Broadway and the Times Bldg. Between the Longacre Bldg. and the Fitzgerald Bldg. on Broadway is the entrance to the George M. Cohan Theatre.

Albion Fellows Bacon (1865-1933; Albion was her first name, not her husband's--she was married to Hilary E. Bacon, a banker) was a "municipal housekeeper" or social reformer in Evansville, Indiana, best known for improving conditions in tenements, in child welfare policy, in city planning, and in public health. She organized the Indiana Housing Association, drafted a state housing law, and served as an officer of the Indiana Child Welfare Association. books.google.com/books?id=v_flvpKK1nUC Today there is an Albion Fellows Bacon Center in Evansville, a shelter whose mission is "to eliminate domestic and sexual violence in our communities through advocacy, education, support services and collaborative partnership." www.albionfellowsbacon.org/
She is buried in Oak Hill Cemetery in Evansville, Indiana - www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GSln=bacon&...;

D. Pineze: It is a little strange, but it turns out that 'Minas Geraes' was the spelling used at the time the ship was commissioned. Many references to that spelling can be found in newspapers of the time, and in other sources. The modern spelling is Gerais, as you pointed out, but Geraes is correct when referring to this ship. Here is one example article about the Minas Geraes from the New York Times in 1908. Thanks for your comment!

The tradition of the President throwing out the first pitch to open the baseball season dates back to the administration of William Howard Taft. It seems that the Griffith Family, who owned the Washington Senators, had tried for years to get the nation's chief executive to the ballpark. This would almost certainly guarantee a big attendance gate in DC, and generate positive newspaper headlines. Presidents prior to this, such as Grover Cleveland (from Buffalo, New York), were concerned attending a baseball game would convey the wrong message to the public about presidential dilagence.
  By the time of President Taft's tenure, this attitude had changed, and our Presidents were able to relax a bit. President Taft, who was from the Cincinnati area, was an avid golfer as well as a baseball fan. He attended a 1909 game, as a spectator only, with his Vice-President James Sherman (from Utica, New York). Opening Day 1910, had to be something of a relief for President Taft, as his duties earlier in the day had him attending a Woman Suffrage gathering, where he was hissed and booed for the views he expressed. This makes me think Big Bill was ready to get to the ballpark.
  The Presidential party for the 1910 'opener' consisted of President and Mrs. Taft, Vice-President Sherman, Secretary of State Charles Baker and Major Archibald Butt, a military aid to the President. The idea of the President actually 'tossing' a ball to the players on the field, may have been hatched on the spot by the Senator's manager Jimmy McAleer, who tried to coax his camera shy star pitcher, Walter Johnson, into to receiving the throw. Walter Johnson begged off the official program, in favor of Senator's catcher Gabby Street. Players from both the Washington Senators and visiting Philadelphia A's gathered near the Executive Box. However, the Taft Administration adeptly interpreted developments in the park, and the President rather than throwing the ball to Gabby Street as planned, directed his throw to the starting pitcher Walter Johnson, who made a shoe top catch. With that throw, a new baseball and presidential tradition, had begun.
  The game was a good one for the Senators, as they defeated the Athletics 3-0, getting their new season off on the right foot. Walter Johnson held the A's hitless until the 7th, and their only hit resulted from a collision between the Senator's right fielder and a fan. The 'Big Train' had to settle for a one-hit, shut-out victory (Bob Feller in 1940 pitched the only opening day no-hitter). The game at Griffith Stadium did have one frightening moment, when a line-drive foul off the bat of the Athletics' 'Home-Run' Baker, pegged Secretary of State Bennett in the head. The danger that looms at every ballgame, was quickly shaken-off by Secretary Bennett, but I'll bet the Griffith family gave the batting screen a new look. President Taft was on hand again to open the 1911 baseball season in Washington, with his military adjunct Major Butt, in this new a well received roll of delivering the first pitch.
  President Taft was a member of the Republican Party. He was the hand picked successor to President Theodore Roosevelt (from Oyster Bay, New York), and was elected in 1908. Major Archie Butt was a Spanish-American War veteran, who served in both the Philippines and Cuba. The Spanish-American War was similar to our present entanglements, in that a struggle persisted for years against entrenched insurgents. President Roosevelt, during his tenure in the White House relied on the opinions of Major Butt, and the two men became good friends. When President Taft succeeded President Roosevelt, he retained Major Butt in the same official capacity, and these two men also became good friends. President Taft's administration was beset by a number of problems that lead him to disagreements with former President Roosevelt. By the next election year, 1912, these disagreements had become so profound that Theodore Roosevelt decided to split from the Republican Party, and to campaign for the White House once more as the Progressive Party candidate (nicknamed the Bull Moose Party due to Roosevelt presence). This rift created deep anxiety for Major Butt, as he would need to decide which of his two friends to support. In order to make up his mind, he took a six week sabbatical to Europe before the 1912 campaign began in earnest. He was scheduled to be back in Washington by mid April, and would have in all likelihood, opened another baseball season with President Taft at Griffith Stadium. However, Major Butt booked his return passage aboard the RMS Titanic, and lost his life at sea when that vessel sank. Due to the Titanic disaster, President Taft did not attend the 1912 baseball opening day, and asked Vice-President Sherman to attend instead, being the first time a VP threw out the first pitch.
  Democrat Woodrow Wilson was elected President in 1912, over incumbent President Taft, and former President Roosevelt. In what seems to be a strange bit of irony, Vice President Sherman died only days before the 1912 election being one of seven Vice-Presidents to die while serving office. President Wilson continued the tradition of the Presidential first pitch, as have all succeeding Presidents except for Jimmy Carter (there was no major league baseball in Washington, DC during President Carter's administration). The only other time a Vice-President 'pinch-hit' for a President on opening day was in 1968, when Hubert Humphrey stood in for President Lyndon Johnson following the assassination of Martin Luther King.

“Mrs. Roger Sullivan ... is content to stay away from politics, and believes more women should follow her example. “On women gaining suffrage she says, 'I think they do more harm then good.' ” [1] Virginia, one of four sisters (Mary Catherine, Helen Marie and Frances Josephine) and one brother (“Bo”), was described at the 1912 Democratic National Convention (at age 17) as ... “She is pure and simple vivacity, life, energy, and everything that thrills. Brennan, an executive of the Independence Packing company in Chicago in 1918, and she died in 1937 at the age of 40. Another dispute over American Indian government is its sovereignty versus that of the states. The federal U.S. government has always been the government that makes treaties with Indian tribes - not the states. Article 1, Section 8 of the Constitution states that “Congress shall have the power to regulate Commerce with foreign nations and among the several states, and with the Indian tribes”.[3] This determined that Indian tribes were separate from the federal or state governments and that the states did not have power to regulate commerce with the tribes, much less regulate the tribes. The states and tribal nations have clashed over many issues such as Indian gaming, fishing, and hunting. American Indians believed that they had treaties between their ancestors and the United States government, protecting their right to fish, while non-Indians believed the states were responsible for regulating commercial and sports fishing.[26] In the case Menominee Tribe v. United States in 1968, it was ruled that “the establishment of a reservation by treaty, statute or agreement includes an implied right of Indians to hunt and fish on that reservation free of regulation by the state”.[27] States have tried to extend their power over the tribes in many other instances, but federal government ruling has continuously ruled in favor of tribal sovereignty. A seminal court case was Worchester v. Georgia. Chief Justice Marshall found that “England had treated the tribes as sovereign and negotiated treaties of alliance with them. The United States followed suit, thus continuing the practice of recognizing tribal sovereignty. When the United States assumed the role of protector of the tribes, it neither denied nor destroyed their sovereignty.”[28] As determined in the Supreme Court case United States v. Nice (1916),[29] U.S. citizens are subject to all U.S. laws even if they also have tribal citizenship.

                                     - from "Tribal Sovereignty in the United States

William T. File was a New York City police officer. He is listed as the second witness for the prosecution in the 1914 retrial in this May 4, 1914, Times article.

From Wiki Jan Kubelík (5 July 1880 – 5 December 1940) was a Czech violinist and composer. He was born in Michle (now part of Prague). His father, a gardener by occupation, was an amateur violinist. He taught his two sons the violin and after discovering Jan's talent, who was aged five at the time, arranged for him to study with Karel Weber and Darel Ondříček. Aged eight he studied at the Prague Conservatory with Otakar Ševčík, of whose technique he became the most famous representative. As a child, he used to practice 10 to 12 hours a day, or "until my fingers started to bleed." After 1898, he toured as a soloist, soon becoming renowned for his great virtuosity and flawless intonation, and his very full and noble tone. He played a Guarneri del Gesù and also two Stradivarius violins: he acquired the 1715 Stradivarius Emperor in 1910. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jan_Kubelik Somehow he doesn't look like a violinist to me. Please reconsider retitling this photo to spell out Japanese. The abbreviation chosen is offensive to many and reverts to the dismissive terminology used during WWII and is out of place in this day and age. -- Found in a search. (?)
It's an abbreviation (with period) seen on the original photo.

Thanks for understanding that no offense is intended. We retain the original title of a photograph as part of preserving the historical record. The Bain News Service photo titles are available from several sources—typed in the set of caption cards consulted while making the scans, hand-written on an older set of cards, and etched on the negatives themselves. Abbreviations are common in each source, and, in this case, the abbreviated term is the only form found.

Sorry, but I do not understand the need to title the photo by what is marked on the photo itself. The photo stands by itself and there is no need to carry the offensive abbreviation to the title. The title of the photo cannot be excused by the claim that it merely reflects what is written on the photo itself, as the choice of title is the free choice of the poster, the Library of Congress, and as such reflects the Library of Congress' own voice. Is it not the Library of Congress' own voice when titling a photo that contains no textual markings? Does it not reflect the best judgment of the Library of Congress regarding the presumed factual (and not editorial) content of the photo? And what if extensive study shows that there exists photos in the collection that is marked in error with incorrect information? Would you in fact title the photo with the incorrect information? I suspect not, as it would be assumed that unless otherwise explicitly stated that the title is written in the voice of the Library of Congress. And are your methods such that any offensive comment written on a photo in your archives will also carry the same title on Flickr? And what is one to make of this photo, where a selective correction to the hand-written note was made when composing its title? Perhaps there can be a reasonable compromise. There exists photos in your collection that makes a clear distinction between the Library of Congress' voice and that of whoever annotated the photo, with square brackets used to mark the poster's (Library of Congress') voice. Perhaps that could be used in this case. e.g.: "[Japanese] gun commanding Seoul (LOC)" Please reconsider retitling this photo. To use such racially loaded and derogatory abbreviations in an area that many would interpret as the Library of Congress' own voice is a very unwise choice and is not fitting the character of such a fine institution. Though I have not viewed all of your photos I have browsed through many of them and nowhere else do I see a similar offense committed. This is a bad precedent to set and is all the more unusual and provocative in its uniqueness with respect to the rest of your collection.

This is history and proper documentation is always important, as affirmed by the staff members from the United States' most important library. Racism is highly improper in the modern day but the racist attitudes of former days (against Asian Americans, African Americans, Native Americans, Jewish Americans, Arab Americans, and others) does need to be properly documented, as any other historical aspect of my nation, however much I may disagree with such attitudes. In this way we may learn from the mistakes of our ancestors. Examples of such shameful, but formerly quite acceptable behavior may be seen at the following photos: www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2787136484/ www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2786280191/ In this particular photo's case, it isn't clear that a racist epithet was intended, as the original photo contains a caption that seems to include an abbreviation (it appears that there is a period), and, in any case, the Library of Congress uses the actual captions on the original photos (which, if incorrect or if need additional clarification, may be discussed here to solve any such difficulty). Editorializing and second-guessing historical texts is our job, not the Library's.

dbadagna: I agree with everything you say. These historical records are treasure for preserving the attitudes, however shortsighted, of the times, and altering the record does history a great disservice. However I am not asking for the artifact to be altered in any way. A title that is contemporaneously applied to a photo does not change the existing historical record. The hand-written marks made at the time on the photo still remains intact to be studied and as testimony to the biases in currency at the time. However let it be understood that subsequent titles applied today are part of a new historical record, reflecting the voice of the person or organization adding the additional title. Yes, the Library of Congress, by adding the title that it chose to add is in essence adding a new mark to the historical record with its own voice. Unfortunately a title applied to the photo in Flickr is not as indelible as the original mark made on the photo. Already it is lost in the historical record that the Library of Congress re-titled 4 similar photos in this series of 7 by adopting the full spelling of "Japanese". The fact that those 4 photos started out on Flickr with a title using the derogatory abbreviation is important in preserving the history of the current debate but for all practical purposes is now lost to history. My purpose for bringing the latter 4 examples up is to illustrate that these little skirmishes over the title and the Library of Congress' reversal in titling them is to illustrate the obvious: that despite all of this at no time was the interpretation, representation, or the content of the original artifact changed. What we do now is part of a new historical record and does not in any way change the pre-existing artifact, record, or history. One interesting observation re. the 2nd of the two photos that you referenced above. In the case of the 2nd photo the Library of Congress dropped the reference to "Savages" in its title even though the scanned image clearly uses this term. Would it be your argument that the Library of Congress now needs to abandon the current title for one that adds the missing word "Savages" of the original hand-written title?
The inconsistencies are duly noted, and it would be very helpful to have an explanation of these inconsistencies from the Library's staff.
Indeed...

Your comments gave us good food for thought! Expanding an abbreviated word in a title to clarify a spelling can be helpful, so we’ve added the fuller spelling in brackets. But this kind of bracketed interpolation is not intended to replace original vocabulary even when a word can cause offense. Quoting an original title is part of preserving historical context by reflecting how an item presented itself when first produced. Just as the Library doesn’t re-title books or movies, we don’t re-title pictures that come to us with formal titles. The unbracketed titles that appear with Library of Congress images in Flickr are not the Library’s own voice. The titles are transcriptions of original text found with the historical photographs. If putting “(LOC)” at the ends of the titles is creating the impression that the Library is writing a new title, we need to rethink adding that indication of where the photo is from. (When a photograph lacks an original title, then a note is provided “Title devised by Library staff” and brackets appear around the entire title. There are also judgment calls when, for example, only a surname or multiple abbreviated words appear on a photo. In those cases, the photo may have been given a quick annotation rather than a formal title, and a descriptive title might be devised with an explanatory note about the title source.) Your comments are helpful for seeing that in the complicated situation with the Bain negatives, where there are multiple sources of historical caption information (two sets of cards and the negatives themselves), varying the title source can cause confusion. Especially when our source of title notes ambiguously cite multiple sources as “Title from unverified data provided by the Bain News Service on the negatives or caption cards.” We’d better stick with a single source-what can be seen in the negative. We’ve started by making sure that the titles for the photos mentioned in the comments above match what’s written on the negatives rather than the caption cards. FYI, the published standard that guides our practice in describing the variety of pictures we preserve is called "Graphic Materials: Rules for Describing Original Items and Historical Collections." It's available online at www.loc.gov/rr/print/gm/graphmat.html.

This was an accident at Stamford, Connecticut, on June 12, 1913. A west-bound express train from Boston apparently did not stop for a signal, and rammed into the (wooden) Skylark chair-car (pictured above), that was stopped at Stamford Station, killing six people and injuring dozens more. There was an extensive investigation amid differing claims that the brakes were either faulty, or were in excellent condition. — excerpted from New York Times. This accident appears to mark the end of major railroads using wooden coaches, with all steel construction becoming the norm.[1] (Note the large wheels of the locomotive are under the wooden coach car.)

A seemingly authoritative article, which even includes a USNA accession number, describes this as coming from the looting of Canada's parliament building: "Public Trophies, Private Plunder The American Harvest after the Battle at York by Robert Malcomson Eleven lions left York with the Americans when Commodore Isaac Chauncey’s squadron finally sailed away, days after the 27 April 1813 capture of the province’s capital. One stood alone while the others were rampant on colourful fields. The lions were among the trophies of war taken by the victorious American expedition. Who picked them up and delivered them to their senior officers has yet to come to light. And any other treasures that disappeared during the plundering of the town have not been discovered. As it is, only some of the trophies remain in existence. The lonely lion still stands alone. It is a wooden carving, painted in gold. Its place was probably on top of a lofty canopy above the speaker’s dais in Upper Canada’s Legislative Assembly at the eastern end of York. Along with other items, it was shipped to Washington for deposit in ‘the archives.’ At some point in the 1800s officials moved it to the institution that evolved into the United States Naval Academy Museum at Annapolis, Maryland. " www.fortyork.ca/images/newsletters/fife-and-drum-2008/fif...

She was launched 1 March 1819 by Washington Navy Yard and commissioned 7 September 1819, Master Commandant J. H. Elton in command. Clearing Norfolk, Virginia, 28 April 1820, Columbus served as flagship for Commodore William Bainbridge in the Mediterranean until returning to Boston 23 July 1821. Serving as a receiving ship after 1833, she remained at Boston in ordinary until sailing to the Mediterranean, 29 August 1842, as flagship for Commodore Charles W. Morgan. On 24 February 1843, she sailed from Genoa, Italy, and reached Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, 29 July to become flagship of the Brazil Squadron, Commodore Daniel Turner. She returned to New York City 27 May 1844 for repairs. After embarking Commodore James Biddle, Commander East Indies Squadron, she sailed 4 June 1845 for Canton, China, where on 31 December, Commodore Biddle exchanged ratified copies of the first American commercial treaty with China. Columbus remained there until April 1846 when she sailed for Japan to attempt opening that country to American commerce. She raised Tokyo Bay 19 July in company with Vincennes, but achieved no success. Recalled at the outbreak of the Mexican-American War Columbus reached Valparaíso, Chile, in December and arrived off Monterey, California, 2 March 1847. Too large to be useful in the California operations, the ship sailed from San Francisco 25 July for Norfolk, arriving 3 March 1848. At Norfolk Navy Yard, Columbus lay in ordinary until 20 April 1861 when she was sunk by withdrawing Union forces to prevent her falling into Confederate hands. Source: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USS_Columbus_(1819)

Page 180 of A Walk in the Yard: A Self-guided Tour of the U.S. Naval Academy books.google.com/books?id=fcOHjVRueZAC&pg=PA180&l... suggests that the statue is at the Naval Academy.

Built in 1815 under the supervision of Samuel Humphreys and Charles Penrose, she was the first vessel to be laid down at the Philadelphia Navy Yard. Franklin sailed on her first cruise on 14 October 1817, when under the command of Master Commandant H. E. Ballard she proceeded from Philadelphia to the Mediterranean. She carried the Hon. Richard Rush, U.S. Minister to England, to his post. Subsequently she was designated flagship of the Mediterranean Squadron, cruising on that station until March 1820. She returned to New York City on 24 April 1820. From 11 October 1821 until 29 August 1824 she served as flagship on the Pacific Squadron. Franklin was laid up in ordinary until the summer of 1843 when she was ordered to Boston as a receiving ship. She continued in this capacity until 1852 at which time she was taken to Portsmouth, New Hampshire, razed and broken up. Source: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USS_Franklin_(1815)

The Bridge, Aberfeldy – Then, Then and Now (100+ years later) Known by several names, the Tay Bridge, General Wade's Bridge or the Aberfeldy Bridge, it has remained in place for more than 275 years. This is a view of the south side of Ailsa Craig ("Fairy Rock"), "a 1,114 feet high volcanic rock that rises from the middle of the Firth of Clyde. With the Ayrshire town of Girvan being only ten miles east of the Craig, some local boat owners offer trips around the rock. Granite was once quarried here to make curling stones. (All curling stones for the Olympic Winter Games have come from this quarry.) "There is a lighthouse on the east coast facing the mainland and a ruined keep of uncertain origins perched on the hillside above. "Today the island is known locally as Paddy's Milestone as it approximately marks the halfway point of the sea journey from Belfast to Glasgow, a traditional route of emigration for many Irish labourers coming to Scotland to seek work. "Ailsa Craig is now uninhabited, the lighthouse having been automated in 1990 and the quarry long since disused. The island is now a bird sanctuary, and huge numbers of gannets nest here ... and a growing number of puffins are choosing to return to the Craig from nearby Glunimore and Sheep Islands."—Wikipedia Click images to view close-ups from other Flickr members: "Fog Horn" "Tower" "Puffins"

This magnificent viaduct carries the Glasgow & South Western railway's main line from Carlisle to Glasgow via Dumfries & Kilmarnock over the River Ayr, just south of Mauchline, Ayrshire.
This viaduct was built 1846 - 1848 using locally quarried sandstone. The railway was opened on 20-05-1850 and remains open today for both freight and passenger traffic.
The central span was the largest span of a masonry arch in the world when built (181 feet, 55 metres) and is the largest in the U.K. The crown of the arch is 175 feet, 54 metres above the River bed.
This building is still open to the public.

"A pleasure pier (in typical Victorian manner) existed (near the end of Bath Street) from 1871 (opened on May 23) until the start of World War I. This was 1250 feet long and had a restaurant and observatory at the end. It cost £7000 and was designed by Sir Thomas Bouch infamously linked to the Tay Bridge Disaster. In a similar ending the iron supports rusted away and the pier was demolished as uneconomic to repair in 1917." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portobello,_Edinburgh

This portrait was clearly often reproduced for souvenirs, etc. See a plate at www.etsy.com/listing/252557691/ridgeway-transfer-ware-mar... and a cabinet card at www.etsy.com/listing/229100178/victorian-historical-cabin... www.alamy.com/stock-photo-mary-queen-of-scots-1542-1587-a... indicates that the original portrait was when Mary Stuart was 27.

www.artnet.com/artists/john-horsburgh/mary-queen-of-scots... indicates that the original is an 1887 oil painting by John Horsburgh. So it was obviously not painted from life. In the background is Holyrood Palace. More on the original oil painting, the artist, and Mary's biography at www.antiques.co.uk/antique/Mary-Queen-of-Scots-1542-1587-...

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holyrood_Palace "The Palace of Holyroodhouse, commonly referred to as Holyrood Palace, is the official residence of the British monarch in Scotland. Located at the bottom of the Royal Mile in Edinburgh, at the opposite end to Edinburgh Castle, Holyrood Palace has served as the principal residence of the Kings and Queens of Scots since the 16th century, and is a setting for state occasions and official entertaining." "The royal apartments in the north-west tower of the palace were occupied by Mary, Queen of Scots, from her return to Scotland in 1561 to her forced abdication in 1567. " en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holyrood_Palace#/media/File:Holyroo... show a sketch of the palace from 1544.

Yes, they are polo players.

what else could they be? The question is, where is this? The presence of the portable flag leads me to suspect they could be on an army base during WWI: "....Joining the USPA in 1902, the Army encouraged their cavalry units to participate in polo to improve their riding ability. From then until World War II, the U.S. Military would play a significant role in the sport of polo." this quote is from www.sportpolo.com/History/default.htm

Checking Newell Bent's American Polo (published by Macmillan in 1929) reveals that there was a series of international matches between American and British teams around this time. There was no such match in 1910, but there were matches in 1909 and 1911 (among other years). Comparing this photo to photos in the book shows similar uniforms (dark shirt, pith-type helmet with dark band around it) for the British teams; for example there's a photo of the 1914 British team on page 189. So I tentatively suggest that this might be a photo of one of the British international polo teams of that era.

BTW, when they say this is 1910s, it means it could be anytime within the decade of 1910-1919, Ammo.

I should have known the guy on the left was a Brit officer.  He has a mustache.

Thanks, budderflyman. I based 1910 on the date given in the stats under the copyright notice. It turns out that there was international polo played in 1910 after all; there are lots of articles in the New York Times covering it. Matches (though not a match for the championship; that match was scheduled but then cancelled due to injury to one of the British riders) were played at Georgian Court in Lakewood, NJ, and at the Meadow Brook Hunt Club on Long Island, NY. Meadow Brook was also a venue for matches later on in the decade.

b - I was thinking that it was Meadow Brook, too, but looking through the 1910 NY Times polo articles shows that games involving the Brits took place at Georgian Court at Lakewood, NJ, (April) and Wildfield Farm at Narragansett Pier, RI (August). Although Meadow Brook polo players were involved in some of these matches, it appears no matches took place at Meadow Brook that year. I want to see if I can place that building in either NJ or RI, but haven't found anything yet.

Given that the photos in this collection are largely in rough chronological order and recent photos have been in early June 1913, this might be one of the matches in a series which was at Meadow Brook. Charles E. Courtney (November 13, 1849 – July 17, 1920) was an American rower and rowing coach from Union Springs, New York. A carpenter by trade, Courtney was a nationally known amateur rower. Courtney never lost as an amateur and finished a total of 88 victories. In 1877 he moved from an amateur to a professional rower, a decision that Courtney would later regret. His professional career was marred by controversy and accusations including cowardice and race fixing. His professional career was best remembered for his controversial losses to Ned Hanlan. Some[who?] believe that the controversies surrounding the Hanlan and Courtney races caused a public backlash against professional rowing that eventually led to its death in the United States. As his rowing career wound down, Courtney became involved in coaching at Cornell University. He coached Cornell’s rowing team from 1883 to 1920. His crews won 14 of 24 Intercollegiate Rowing Association Championship Regatta, varsity eight oared titles. He kept his position until he died in the summer of 1920. Source: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_E._Courtney
See Charles E. Courtney in HistoryForge for Tompkins County: tompkins.historyforge.net/people/9015

No "Henion" in the NYT for 1913. But Hennion is the name of the Prefect of Police in Paris. Could this be him? Some of the photos in www.prefecture-police-paris.interieur.gouv.fr/documentati... look as though they could be him. And one is in a similar office. His predecessor, Lepine, resigned in March 1913. Hennion was mentioned in the NYT on April 20, 1913 when Isadora Duncan's children were drowned in Paris -- in a car that ran away when the chauffeur got out without turning the car off. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9F03E2D81139E633A... His March 1915 obituary was in the NYT query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A0CE0DC153AE633A...

Célestin Hennion CVO (8 September 1862 - 14 March 1915) was a French police officer who rose to head the Prefecture of Police (French: Préfecture de Police). He is notable for his reorganisation of the Préfecture and the introduction of the Tiger's Brigades (French: Brigades du Tigre). In France, he is considered the father of modern policing. Source: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Celestin_Hennion

Ernest Augustus (Ernest Augustus Christian George; German: Ernst August Christian Georg; 17 November 1887 – 30 January 1953), reigning Duke of Brunswick (2 November 1913 – 8 November 1918), was a grandson of George V, whom the Prussians deposed in 1866. The last reigning monarch of the House of Hanover, Ernest Augustus was a direct descendant of Henry the Lion. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Princess_Viktoria_Luise_of_Prussia Princess Victoria Louise of Prussia, Duchess of Brunswick (Victoria Louise Adelaide Matilda Charlotte; German: Viktoria Luise Adelheid Mathilde Charlotte; 13 September 1892 – 11 December 1980) was the only daughter and the seventh child of William II, German Emperor and Empress Augusta Victoria – at the time of her death, she was their last surviving child. Princess Victoria Louise is the maternal grandmother of Queen Sophie of Spain and the former King Constantine II of the Hellenes.
Ernst August and Victoria Louise were married. Prince Oskar is her brother.

Another possibility, compare the photos: More likely a native New Jersey man like me, and a member of the Early Birds of Aviation, for which I have been writing biographies in Wikipedia for. Alan Ramsay Hawley (July 29, 1869 – February 16, 1938) was one of the early aviators in the United States. In 1910 he won the Gordon Bennett International Balloon Race with his balloon America II, aided by his friend and fellow aviator Augustus Post. After landing in the wilderness in Quebec, Canada they spent a week traveling back to civilization before they were able to send a telegram. He was also the President of the Aero Club of America during a five year period. Source: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alan_Ramsay_Hawley

Marion Gaynor (b. 1897) was the fourth daughter of New York City Mayor William Jay Gaynor (1849-1913), the only New York mayor (so far) to be the target of an assassination attempt (he recovered enough to resume the duties of his office, but died three years later from the after-effects of his injuries). en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Jay_Gaynor Marion Gaynor was in the news in 1914 when she married real estate heir Ralph Heyward Isham, in a simple service reflecting her mourning status four months after the Mayor's death. The Ishams were reported separated in 1915, and were divorced in 1920.

Mrs. Gaynor-Isham reported improving in an article clipped from the 1914 February 10 edition of the Los Angeles Examiner in the Claremont Colleges Digital Library ccdl.libraries.claremont.edu/u?/lsc,3879
Miss Gaynor was married at age 16: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9C00EFDB1730E7...

This was taken on Monday June 2, 1913. "Edward Payson Weston, America's famous long-distance pedestrian..." Veteran walker Mr. Weston was setting off from the plaza of the College of the City of New York (139th street) at noon for a walk to Chicago - a distance of 999 miles. He reckoned to make 25 miles per day. Here is the link to the relevant New York Times article of Sunday June 1, 1913: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9404EEDA143FE633A... Remarkably, Mr. Weston covered the New York City to Chicago walk over 36 waling daysin 1909. Here is his wikipedia entry which encapsulates his pedestrian career, he lived 1839 - 1929: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edward_Payson_Weston
Thanks so much lifeasdaddy, for all of the useful information.  We'll add the information about Weston to the title, and include the date next time we revise this record.

In 1908 she married Prince Vilhelm, Duke of Södermanland (17 June 1884 - 5 June 1965), the second son of King Gustav V of Sweden. On May 11, 1913, according to the NYT, query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9801E0D7173FE633A... they were rumored to have been selected to rule Albania. "It is rumored that Prince William, second son of the King of Sweden, and his wife, Princess Marie, have been selected by the powers of the Triple Entente as the rulers of the new Kingdom of Albania, which is to be formed on the conclusion of peace between Turkey and the Allies." But by November 1913 the marriage was over and she was back in Russia.

Iron Mask was a 1908 dark bay gelding sired by Disguise, out of the imported mare Royal Rose (sired by Royal Hampton).  He was bred & owned by James R. Keene.  The horse died in 1916.

The photo is most likely from 1910, when he ran in prominent New York races for two-year-olds.  Due to a wagering ban, there was no organized racing in the Northeast from late 1910 -  early 1913.

The jockey is Roscoe Troxler, who won the 1906 Kentucky Derby on Sir Huon.

These artillery exercises are all on what is still a sports field between the academy buildings and the water. I've been trying to find a current picture from the water. Anyone who sails regularly into Annapolis uses the Academy Chapel , the State House, and St. Mary's as landmarks. But you have to be pretty far away to see them all -- not likely to be a good photo. The best I've found so far to prove where the exercises are happening are the panorama I link to from the photo mentioned above combined with travel.webshots.com/photo/2720983120013808429BvyNsp. In this one, you are looking from a boat towards the eastern end of Dahlgren Hall (the armory). The lights on poles in front of Dahlgren Hall illuminate the field where the artillery exercises are going on in the 1913 photo.

On June 4, 1913, the next day, the Wyoming would be in town, immediately after leading the fleet for the celebrations associated with unveiling the Maine Monument.. See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USS_Wyoming_(BB-32) "Shifting to Annapolis, Maryland on 4 June, Wyoming embarked a contingent of United States Naval Academy midshipmen and took the young officers-to-be on a summer cruise off the coast of New England that lasted into late August." Although the Naval Academy commissioning (graduation) ceremonies are now usually in late May, dates I found for 1912 and 1918 were in the first week in June. So this is probably a crowd of family and friends waiting for some part of the festivities.

The majority of individuals in this photography are Shia Muslim clerics/imams. Omar your assesment is correct as this is the typical garb worn in Iran by the religous scholars. 

One will note that some of the individuals are wearing black turbans and some are wearing white. The black turbans are a distinction among the scholars as who is a decendent of the Prophet Muhammad (pbuh) through his daughter Lady Fatimah Zahra (as).

Of the taller individuals in the back wearing fezes, we can make some assumptions that they are either non-clerical individuals or they are Sunni Muslims who are clerics.

One last comment and hopefully someone can confirm its autheticity, is this photograph was taken at the time of a academic and scholarly debate between the 2 main sects in Islam in the city of Peshawar, Pakistan. The debates themselves were documented in a book known as Peshawar Nights. In a very old copy I have, I found a print of this very picture in that book which is why I believe this picture was taken at that time.

From 1911 Encyclopedia Britannica:
   "The Modern Nestorians.—The Nestorians or East Syrians (Surayi) of Turkey and Persia now inhabit a district bounded by Lake Urmia, or Urumia, on the east, stretching westwards into Kurdistan, to Mosul on the south, and nearly as far as Van on the north . They are divided into the Persian Nestorians of the plain of Azerbaijan, and the Turkish Nestorians, inhabiting chiefly the sanjak of Hakkiari in the vilayet of Van, who are subdivided into the Rayat or subject, and the Ashiret or tribal, the latter being semi-independent in their mountain fastnesses"

Hello! Very interesting photo, but what is the evidence for it showing a Nestorian bishop with his entourage? There is a similar tableau from the 1890s in J. de Morgan et al., Mission scientifique en Perse, II, 1895: plate XI “Fête du faux emir à Saoudj-Boulagh” (undated black/white photograph by S. E. Seif-ed-Din Khân Sérdâr); available OA via HATHI hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015005789774?urlappend=%3Bseq=71 This scene shows a "mir-e nowruzi" (lit. “The prince of the New Year festivities”) with his entourage; the "mir-e nowruzi" is one of the rituals of the traditional Nowruz festival in Iran; cf. www.iranicaonline.org/articles/nowruz-index -- Dagmar Riedel

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/islamic_books]: The only real evidence is that the caption "Persia - Nestorian Archbishop, his secy and servants " was recorded by the Bain news agency. Not all Bain captions have proved accurate, although the great majority of people and places do seem to be identified correctly, give or take spelling mistakes. But, I find that the same picture is identified as being of Kurdish soldiers by the Brooklyn Museum. See www.brooklynmuseum.org/opencollection/objects/161259/Kurd... But the same caption appears to be applied to all the photos in the set, and some of them are more clearly soldiers.
The costumes are somewhat similar to that of the Nestorian priest in luna.library.wmich.edu/luna/servlet/detail/WMUwmu~85~85~4...

Thanks, swanq, for the reference in the photograph in the BMA! And yes, I agree about the "Iranian Christian" feel of the costumes, cf. exhibitions.cul.columbia.edu/exhibits/show/quran/item/6126 The area for which Morgan reported about the ritual of the "faux emir" is part of Kurdestan, and Morgan published a scholarly report about field work in Iran: www.worldcat.org/oclc/5660382 In general, this field report is considered a reliable source for Iran in the 1890s. These observations can possibly be reconciled, because Nowruz is not an Islamic, Jewish, or Christian festival: it is an Iranian festival. Moreover, Christians have been living in Iran since the 3rd century: www.iranicaonline.org/articles/christianity-viii Therefore, I am still wondering whether the scene shows a real or a mock bishop. The many men with weapons seem to me a bit too martial for a Christian dignitary, rather militia than priests. But a militia would be okay for the "faux emir" -- as described in Morgan's text. Does the Bain collection include other images of other Christian dignitaries in Iran in the midst of their entourage? If there are not any contemporary photographs of Christian bishops, how about Muslim theologians and their entourage?

Gabriel Heatter Frederick D. Owen and nine-year-old George Hearst – about to pull a silken cord that will remove the flags and unveil the National Maine Monument, Memorial Day, May 30, 1913. Gabriel Heatter was a renowned American radio commentator, who began his career as a sidewalk campaigner for William Randolph Hearst during the publishing giant's 1906 mayoral campaign. Frederick D. Owen served with the Department of Public Buildings and Grounds, in Washington, DC., and also did the actual unveiling of the McKinley memorial in Canton, the Harrison memorial in Indianapolis and many others." [1] [2] Master George Hearst's father, newspaper mogul William Randolph Hearst, had popularized the slogan "Remember the Maine" as a way of gaining up support for war with Spain over the blowing up of the battleship Maine in Havana harbor fifteen years earlier. W. R. Hearst also spearheaded the movement to create the Maine Monument. Attilio Piccirilli sculptured a statue of Columbia Triumphant driving a seashell chariot. It is located at the Columbus Circle entrance to Central Park, New York. --Complete coverage of events: New York Times

That can't be Gabriel Heatter. Heatter was born in 1890 (and died in 1972). In 1913 he would have been only 23 years old.

Wystan:  I agree that the gentleman on the left cannot be Gabriel Heatter, 1890-1972.  The ribbon on his lapel indicates he is a member of the National Maine Monument Committee, but his name is not given.  When we update the record, we'll add the identity of George Hearst, but leave the other man unidentified. Thanks for the heads up!

Now, some 3½ years later, I have the correct identification for the gentleman standing with little George Hearst at the unveiling of the Maine Monument in New York City. (That old British saying comes to mind ... "A change is as good as a rest" ;) This is, of course, Frederick D. Owen of the Department of Public Buildings and Grounds, Washington, DC. The New York Times reported that Frederick Owen also did the actual unveiling of the "McKinley memorial in Canton, the Harrison memorial in Indianapolis and many others." [1] [2] Two Independent Verifications I have included a link to a confirming captioned photograph of Frederick D. Owen from 1910. He is also identified in a 1915 photograph at a cornerstone laying ceremony at Arlington National Cemetery, in the Harris & Ewing Collection at The Library of Congress. I have also modified/edited the original description to reflect the corrected information.

Grace Porter Hopkins (b.1873), daughter of John Warren and Helen M. (Stoddard) Porter, married Randolph D. Hopkins in1893. Like the other five women in the above photograph, she was a founding Director of the Woman's National Democratic League, Inc., in 1912. She was Vice President, D.C. Federation of Woman's Clubs; Vice President, Woman's National Press Association; Secretary Woman's National Democratic League and Officer, Louisa Adams Chapter D.A.R. Hopkins was co-editor of the popular The Economy Administration Cook Book in 1913 -- a collection of recipes that were delicious and submitted by the Wives of Senators, Congressmen and other notable people. It was put together to give a collection of wholesome economical recipes, as stated in the book “The subject of the high cost of living is one that is uppermost in the minds of the people of the present day universally.” Mrs. Hopkins was also a Washington correspondent for a syndicate of newspapers. Harvey Washington Wiley (October 30, 1844 - June 30, 1930) was a noted chemist best known for his leadership in the passage of the landmark Pure Food and Drug Act of 1906 and his subsequent work at the Good Housekeeping Institute laboratories. He was the first commissioner of the US Food and Drug Administration. ... In 1912, Wiley resigned and took over the laboratories of Good Housekeeping magazine, where he continued his work on behalf of the consuming public. His disapprobation of "drugged" products included as the caffeine in cola drinks, against which he warned as vehemently as he would have against the cocaine they had once contained. In a famous action brought against the Coca-Cola company in 1911, he contended that it was illegal to use the name Coca-Cola when there was no actual cocaine in the drink, and also that it was illegal for it to contain caffeine as an additive. Perversely, this was as much as to say that the product ought to have contained cocaine and not caffeine. Still, the case was a landmark in developing standards for truth in labelling. Source: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harvey_W._Wiley

Rhinelander Waldo (New York City, May 24, 1877 – Garrison, New York, August 13, 1927) was appointed the 7th New York City Fire Commissioner by Mayor William Jay Gaynor on January 13, 1910, and resigned his position on May 23, 1911 (less than two months after the deadly Triangle Shirtwaist Factory fire) to accept an appointment as the 8th New York City Police Commissioner. On December 31, 1913, he was dismissed by the outgoing Acting Mayor Ardolph Kline. Among other achievements in office, Waldo contributed to the motorization of both departments.

Hugo Osterhaus (born June 15, 1851, Belleville, Illinois - died June 11, 1927, Castle Point, New York) was an Admiral in the United States Navy. He was appointed Midshipman September 22, 1865 and received his commission as an Ensign July 13, 1871. He was the son of Civil War Major General Peter J. Osterhaus (1823-1917) and father of Navy Admiral Hugo Wilson Osterhaus (1878-1972) and is buried on Arlington National Cemetery.

R.A.C. Smith (February 22, 1857 - July 27, 1933) was the Commissioner of Docks in New York City.

John Sibley Whalen (born June 30, 1868 in Rochester, New York) was Secretary of State of New York from 1907 to 1908.

Eugene Noble Foss, (September 24, 1858-September 13, 1939) was an American Representative and governor from Massachusetts, as well as brother of George Edmund Foss.

William Jay Gaynor (1849 – September 10, 1913) was an American politician from New York City, associated with the Tammany Hall political machine. He served as mayor of the City of New York from 1910 to 1913, as well as stints as a New York Supreme Court Justice from 1893 to 1909.

Her Imperial Highness Grand Duchess Maria Pavlovna of Russia, known as "Maria Pavlovna the Younger" (In Russian Великая Княгиня Мария Павловна) (April 6/April 18, 1890 - December 13, 1958) was the daughter of Grand Duke Paul Alexandrovich of Russia and Alexandra Georgievna of Greece. She was usually called "Marie," the French version of her name.
Her paternal grandparents were Alexander II of Russia and Empress Maria Alexandrovna. Her maternal grandparents were George I of Greece and Grand Duchess Olga Konstantinovna of Russia, his queen consort.
In 1905 Marie was engaged to Prince Wilhelm, Duke of Södermanland (June 17, 1884 - June 5, 1965), the second son of King Gustav V of Sweden

Wow. This is a good picture of President Taft, although you can not really make out his body size. He was the largest president of all time weighing over 300 pounds. The picture also conveys how big steam cars at the time were in relation to President Taft.

This automobile is a Pierce-Arrow, not a White steamer. They have very different shaped hoods and radiators. The name "Pierce-Arrow is visible on the rear hub cap in another photo. The radiator cap indicates that this is a gasoline automobile.

I considered Pierce-Arrow, but desided the shape of the hood looked like a Packard.  Early models of Pierce-Arrow didn't have headlights that faired into the fenders, so you are probably correct. 

Taft is clearly the largest man in the picture.

possibly: STERLING, John Allen, (1857-1918) (brother of Thomas Sterling), a Representative from Illinois; born near Le Roy, McLean County, Ill., February 1, 1857; attended the public schools, and was graduated from the Illinois Wesleyan University at Bloomington in 1881; superintendent of the public schools of Lexington, Ill., 1881-1883; studied law; was admitted to the bar in December 1884 and commenced practice in Bloomington, Ill.; State’s attorney of McLean County 1892-1896; member of the Republican State central committee 1896-1898; elected as a Republican to the Fifty-eighth and to the four succeeding Congresses (March 4, 1903-March 3, 1913); one of the managers appointed by the House of Representatives in 1912 to conduct the impeachment proceedings against Robert W. Archbald, judge of the United States Commerce Court; unsuccessful candidate for reelection to the Sixty-third Congress; elected to the Sixty-fourth and Sixty-fifth Congresses and served from March 4, 1915, until his death near Pontiac, Ill., as the result of an automobile accident, October 17, 1918; interment in Park Hill Cemetery, Bloomington, Ill.

THOMAS, Charles Spalding, (1849-1934) a Senator from Colorado; born in Darien, McIntosh County, Ga., December 6, 1849; attended private schools in Georgia and Connecticut; served briefly in the Confederate Army; graduated from the law department of the University of Michigan at Ann Arbor in 1871; admitted to the bar in 1871; moved to Colorado and commenced practice in Denver, Colo.; Denver city attorney in 1875 and 1876; member of the Democratic National Committee 1884-1896; unsuccessful candidate for election to the United States House of Representatives in 1884, to the Senate in 1888 and 1895, and to the governorship in 1894; Governor of Colorado 1899-1901; elected as a Democrat to the United States Senate in 1913 to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Charles J. Hughes, Jr.; reelected in 1914, and served from January 15, 1913, to March 3, 1921; unsuccessful candidate on the Nationalist ticket for reelection in 1920; chairman, Committee on Woman Suffrage (Sixty-third and Sixty-fourth Congresses), Committee on Coast Defenses (Sixty-fifth Congress), Committee on Pacific Railroads (Sixty-sixth Congress); resumed the practice of law; died in Denver, Colo., June 24, 1934; the remains were cremated and the ashes interred in Fairmount Cemetery. source: bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=T000160

Nathan Crook Twining (17 January 1869 – 4 July 1924) was an Admiral of the United States Navy. Twining was born on 17 January 1869 at Boscobel, Wisconsin. He was appointed a Naval Cadet in 1885 and graduated from the United States Naval Academy on 7 June 1889. During the Spanish-American War, he served in Iowa (BB-4) in Cuban waters and later was executive officer of Kearsarge (BB-5) when that ship circumnavigated the globe with the "Great White Fleet." He commanded Tacoma (C-18) during the bombardment of Vera Cruz, Mexico in 1914. During World War I, he served as Chief of Staff for Admiral William Sims, Commander of Naval Forces in European waters, and was also a member of the Allied War Council. Rear Admiral Twining retired early in 1923 and died on 4 July 1924 at Nantucket, Massachusetts. TWINING, NATHAN CROOK REAR ADM US NAVY DATE OF DEATH: 07/04/1924 BURIED AT: SECTION 4 SITE 2892 ARLINGTON NATIONAL CEMETERY source: www.arlingtoncemetery.net/nctwining.htm

PERKY, Kirtland Irving, a Senator from Idaho; born in Smithville, Wayne County, Ohio, February 8, 1867; attended the public schools and graduated from Ohio Northern University at Ada in 1888; studied law at the University of Iowa, Iowa City; admitted to the bar in 1890 and commenced practice in Wahoo, Saunders County, Nebr.; moved to Albion, Idaho, 1894; district judge of the fourth judicial district of the State of Idaho in 1901; moved to Boise, Idaho, and continued the practice of law; appointed as a Democrat to the United States Senate to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Weldon B. Heyburn and served from November 18, 1912, to February 5, 1913, when a successor was elected and qualified; resumed the practice of law in Boise; moved to Los Angeles, Calif., in 1923 and continued the practice of law until his death there on January 9, 1939; interment in Forest Lawn Cemetery, Glendale, Calif.

NORRIS, George William, (1861-1944) a Representative and a Senator from Nebraska; born on a farm near Clyde, Sandusky County, Ohio, on July 11, 1861; attended the district schools, Baldwin University, Berea, Ohio, and the Northern Indiana Normal School at Valparaiso; taught school while studying law; graduated from the law department of Valparaiso (Ind.) University in 1883 and was admitted to the bar the same year; continued teaching until he moved to Beaver City, Furnas County, Nebr., in 1885; engaged in the practice of law; county attorney of Furnas County for three terms; district judge of the fourteenth district 1895-1902; moved to McCook, Red Willow County, Nebr., in 1899; elected as a Republican to the Fifty-eighth and to the four succeeding Congresses (March 4, 1903-March 3, 1913); did not seek renomination in 1912, having become a candidate for Senator; one of the managers appointed by the House of Representatives in 1912 to conduct the impeachment proceedings against Judge Robert W. Archbald; elected as a Republican to the United States Senate in 1912; reelected in 1918, 1924, and 1930, and as an Independent in 1936, and served from March 4, 1913, to January 3, 1943; unsuccessful candidate for reelection in 1942; chairman, Committee on the Five Civilized Tribes of Indians (Sixty-fifth Congress), Committee on Patents (Sixty-sixth Congress), Committee on Agriculture and Forestry (Sixty-seventh through Sixty-ninth Congresses), Committee on the Judiciary (Sixty-ninth through Seventy-second Congresses); known as the “father of the TVA,” the first of that project’s dams was named Norris Dam; retired from public life; died in McCook, Nebr., September 2, 1944; interment in Memorial Park Cemetery. source: bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=N000139 here is link to info on the Archbald impeachment: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_W._Archbald

Constantine I King of the Hellenes Constantine I was King of Greece from 1913 to 1917 and from 1920 to 1922. He was Commander-in-Chief of the Hellenic Army during the unsuccessful Greco-Turkish War of 1897 and led the Greek forces during the successful Balkan Wars of 1912-1913, in which Greece captured Thessaloniki, and doubled in area and population. I agree that his bride is Victoria Margaret daughter of Prince Friedrich Leopold of Prussia and Louise Sophie of Schleswig-Holstein-Sonderburg-Augustenburg. "Heinrich XXXIII Prinz Reuss zu Köstritz was born on July 26, 1879, in Austria. He was the son of Heinrich VII Prinz Reuss zu Köstritz and Marie Alexandrine Anne Sophie Auguste Helene Prinzessin von Sachsen-Weimar-Eisenach. "He married, secondly, Allene Tew, daughter of Charles Henry Tew and Janet Smith, on April 10, 1929, at Paris, France. He and Allene Tew were divorced on 31 October 31, 1935, at Paris, France. He died on November 15, 1942, at age 63 at Stonsdorf. "-- the Peerage There are other photographs on Flicka of Prince Heinrich XXXIII with his (first) wife, and family: "Prinz Heinrich XXXIII. Mrs. Gillespie and Mary Diehl were apparently policewomen in Philadelphia, assigned to work in railroad stations. 2 May 1913, Oswego Daily Times: Philadelphia Has Two Policewomen They Are Stalwart Amazons And Able to Cope with Any Males of the "Masher" Type Philadelphia, May 2--Commuters scurrying through the Broad Station today on their respective ways to the daily grind stopped, craned their necks and stood aghast at the curious spectacle of a large woman dressed in a military cut blue suit, with her hand firmly upon the shoulder of a well dressed young man, escorting him hurriedly out of the waiting room. [....] The "lady copper" was Mrs. Mary Diehl, a superbly formed 1913 Amazonian style of woman, with pleasing but stern features and a military bearing. She is on the Broad street station beat and her chief work is to protect young girls and women against the glances and advances of roysterers and mashers. [....] Philadelphia has two such policewomen. They have been on the force about four weeks. They are Mrs. Diehl and Miss L. M. Gillespie. Both are detailed at railroad stations but they have full authority to act as guardians of the peace in all sections of the city alike. They are provided with revolver, black-jack, nippers, and badge, all identical with those of other members of the Philadelphia police force. [....] Found this as a pdf online but it has a long link... search "L. M. Gillespie" and badge to find the link.

This seems quite likely to be the former Alice Cornelia Thaw. From profilesintime.blogspot.com/2007/02/benjamin-thaw.html "Alice Thaw (January 2, 1880 - ? March 1969) - Baptized 11 DEC 1881 at 3rd Presbyterian Church, Pittsburgh, Allegheny, Pennsylvania Alice Cornelia (Thaw) Seymour Whitney; in a much talked of international match, she became the Countess of Yarmouth. She married George Francis Alexander Seymour (20 October 1871, d. 16 February 1940), the son of Hugh de Grey Seymour, 6th Marquess of Hertford and Hon. Mary Hood, on 27 April 1903 in Pittsburgh. It is said that the earl extorted money from her at her wedding and promptly deserted her. Her marriage to George Francis Alexander Seymour was annulled in 1908. He was styled Lord Hertford; he died in 1940, aged 68 and childless, and his titles passed to his nephew. Later (before 1914), Alice Thaw became Mrs. Geoffrey G. Whitney (Geoffrey Gordon Whitney was born July 21, 1882 in Boston). Their estate was at Woods Hole. " The engagement announcement on December 19, 1912 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9D03E4DA1E3AE633A... has a different middle initial for her future husband, but her May 1955 obituary at select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FA0A14F8345B167B... (subscripton required), gives his name as Geoffrey G. Whitney. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A07E5DA173FE633A... dates the wedding as April 22, 1913. So the photo may be from around the time of the wedding. She was the sister of Harry K. Thaw, husband of Evelyn Nesbit. See www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2929579164/

NYTimes reported in 1913:
"HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 22. -- The townsfolk here are waiting with much curiosity for the suffrage pageant which Gen. Rosalie Jones has arranged for next Saturday afternoon. On that day those interested in the suffrage cause, will march from Mineola to this place. At the trolley junction the parade will be reviewed by Assemblyman O'Keefe and officials of Nassau County."
Flower girls in the springtime would make sense, too. Two days later, also in the New York Times:
"Hempstead, N.Y., May 24. -- Three miles of public highway between Mineola and Hempstead were crowded this afternoon with a long line of automobiles from all parts of Nassau County as they followed the suffrage pageant, in which 500 women and a few men marched as enthusiastic upholders of the cause."

Greetings! I am currently writing an article on the 1913 suffragette pageant that occurred here on Long Island. The woman in the center (third from left) was identified in period newspapers as Marjorie Cullen. The woman on the far left was identified as Susanne Byman. The woman who is second from far right was identified as Rose Roth. If you find any images of a horse drawing a wagon associated with the Rosalie Jones suffrage march on Washington DC, the horse may be the famed "Lausanne" ('the bargain horse") - so named because "he was purchased for $59.98, reduced from $60" to pull the Suffrage Army's yellow wagon on the march to Washington. Lausanne became an part of the news coverage during the trek (he apparently did not participate in the Long Island pageant, as he had passed away by then). - Daniel E Russell Former City Historian Glen Cove, Long Island -- Found in a search. "SS Imperator was an ocean liner built for the Hamburg America Line (German: Hamburg-Amerikanische Packetfahrt-Actien-Gesellschaft or HAPAG) launched in 1912. She was the first of a trio of successively larger Hamburg America ships that included SS Vaterland and SS Bismarck built by the line for transatlantic passenger service. At the time of her launch in May 1912, she was the largest passenger ship in the world superseding the sunken RMS Titanic. During World War I, the ship remained in port in Hamburg. After the war she was briefly commissioned into the United States Navy as USS Imperator (ID-4080) and employed for returning American troops from Europe. Following her U.S. Navy service, Imperator was handed over to Britain's Cunard Line as part of war reparations, and she sailed as the flagship RMS Berengaria for the final decade of her career."" An excerpt from Wikipedia en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SS_Imperator I also note that she had a fire in 1913. F scott Fitzgerald set his "The Beautiful and the Dammed" aboard the RMS Berengaria, The Imperator's rechristened name after the war.

There seem to be conflicting dates: New York Times article (above) dated May 22d (a Thursday) ... reports the pageant will be "next Saturday afternoon" (May 24, 1913) ["The parade will start from Mineola at 2:15 o'clock."]. The second New York Times article, dated May 24, 1913, refers to pageant taking place "this afternoon" (Saturday). The date etched into the Bain News Service negative (above) -- as well as on some other negatives apparently taken at the same time -- is "May 25, 1913" (Sunday). Some, such as "Suffrage news girls", appear to bear a date of "May 26, 1913" (Monday).

This is likely Major Richard Sylvester (1859-1930), Chief of Police of Washington, DC. "Sylvester was harshly criticized by leaders in the woman's suffrage movement, and others, for the failure of the police to protect participants in the March, 1913, Washington woman's suffrage parade from the crowds on Pennsylvania Avenue." –New York Times Sylvester was the first president of the International Association of Chiefs of Police (IACP), and "was widely regarded as the father of police professionalism. He advocated a citizen-soldier model, and was responsible for development of the many paramilitary aspects of policing." He coined the phrase "the third degree" in the context of interrogation.

Summary: This is Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson walking beside Chief of Staff of the Army Major General Leonard Wood at President Taft's New Year's Day reception, January 1, 1913 in Washington D. C. The written caption on the plate here reads: SEC'Y STIMSON & OFFICERS JAN 1, '13 Now that we know it is January 1, 1913, and knowing that Henry L. Stimson was Secretary of War at that time makes it a good deal easier to find what the hoo ha of military dress uniforms and top hats is about. New York Times advanced search brings us to: [ query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9900EEDA123BE633A... ] For these headlines and quotes - "THOUSAND IN CROWD AT TAFT'S RECEPTION; Thirty-eight Nations Represented at Brilliant New Year Gathering at White House." + "WASHINGTON, Jan. 1. -- Long before 11 o'clock this morning, which was the hour announced for the opening of the President's New Year reception, thousands of persons stood in line from the entrance gate of the White House to the west door of the State Department." For comparison photos of Maj-Gen Wood see here: and here: www.wood.army.mil/MGLeonardwood.htm Here is the Citation for his Congressional Medal of Honor: history.amedd.army.mil/moh/woodl.htm www.wood.army.mil/engrmag/Maneuver Support Magazine/PDFs for Summer 2008/Roberts.pdf

From what I gather from contemprary accounts, news service photogs in the early days of the business were particularly aggressive about trying to control picture opportunities such as this. They wouldn't be shy about asking a non-luminary to step out of the frame. If any shutterbug on this day suggested to the chauffer that he move aside, Mr or Mrs Knox obviously vetoed that idea. 

It is perfectly clear from many last will bequests of the wealthy that they greatly valued their closest employees. John Daniel Crimmins (1844-1917) was one of New York City's most prominent citizens of Irish descent in the late nineteenth century. "Born in New York City and raised in an upper middle class home. After graduating from St. Franics Xavier College High School, he joined his father's contracting firm as a partner, taking over as president in 1873. Under his direction, the firm experienced rapid growth, employing up to 12,000 people at its height. His firm played a prominent role in the renovation and construction of what would become "modern New York City," building most of the city's elevated railways, many of its buildings, hospitals, and churches, and laying the first underground lines for telegraph and telephone cables. Much of Crimmins' success was attributed to his innovative use of the steam drill for excavation work. He was married to Lily Lalor Crimmins (1849-1888) and had at least three children." —Excerpted Georgetown University Libraries

This event is probably the Diplomatic Corps Reception at the Pan American Building, Washington D. C. on New Year's Day 1913. These distinctive gates are at the front of the Pan American Building, Washington D.C.. See this photograph for confirmation : www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2179870664/ John Barrett, a very experienced diplomat, was Director General of the Pan American Union (and its' predeccessor) from 1907 to 1924. [ ref. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Barrett_(diplomat) ] On New Year's Day 1913, President Taft hosted his New Year's Day Reception at the White House, which many of the Diplomatic Corps attended. [ query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9900EEDA123BE633A... ] However, on that same day and also referred to in that New York Times article: "Second only in importance to the White House Reception was the breakfast at the Pan-American Union Building where the Secretary of State and Mrs. Knox entertained the members of the Diplomatic Corps and their families, withthe members of the Committees of the House and Senate dealing with our foreign relations. To welcome these guests the Secretary and Mrs. Knox dropped out of the White House receving line after the passing of the Supreme Court. In the Pan-American Building they received standing at the head of the marble stairway overlooking the patio. The breakfast was served in the Hall of the Americas, regarded as the most beautiful formal apartment in Washington." There is also a photograph of P. C. Knox, the Secretary of State with his wife and the same herald with megaphone on the same steps as those depicted above here : www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/3314477848/

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Organization_of_American_States has a second photo that shows the gates of the Pan American Union Building more clearly -- to confirm lifeasdaddy's hypothesis. See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:OAS_Building_-_DC.jpg

April 28, 1912 "With the advent of Spring weather and the roads in good condition, the Ladies' Four-in-Hand Driving Club, an organization of enthusiastic horsewomen of this city, will inaugurate the 1912 coaching season with daily trips between the Colony Club and Rockingstone, Bronx Park. The first trip will be made May 6 and continue daily until further notice, according to the plans arranged with the officers of the club and Morris E. Howlett, the coaching whip." ... May 11, 1915 "The famous old coach Liberty, which has a history dating back to 1893, when James Gordon Bennett used it in trips from Paris to Rouen, and which Alfred G. Vanderbilt often drove in this country, will on next Friday be placed in service between the Biltmore and the Gedney Farms Hotel in White Plains. John McE. Bowman, President of the Biltmore, is the sponsor for the undertaking. ..." [End of First Paragraph]

Found this at the National Sporting Library's website:

"The Ladies' Four-in-Hand Driving Club was formed in New York City in 1901 by several prominent society women who took an interest in driving.  The club was a counterpart to the city’s famed Coaching Club, many members of which were husbands, fathers, and brothers to the members of the Ladies’ Club. The Ladies’ Club took regular trips to the different boroughs as well as longer road trips to destinations in New Jersey, Pennsylvania, and Connecticut; for a short time they even ran a small shuttle service through Manhattan.  Under the tutelage of renowned driving instructor Morris Howlett, most of the members became quite accomplished drivers.  Each year, the Club held a parade and review through Central Park onto Fifth Avenue.  The Club’s founder and president was Helen Benedict Hastings, wife of the famous architect Thomas Hastings, designer of the New York Public Library, the front façade of the U. S. Capitol Building, and the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier at Arlington Cemetery.  Other notable members of the Ladies’ Club included Mrs. Arthur Iselin (vice president), Louisa Gulliver Sheldon (secretary and treasurer), Marion Hollins, and Harriet Alexander.  The Club flourished until automobile traffic on the city streets made coaching impossible."

As Vixen is bedecked from stem to stern with flags, this appears to be the launching of the steam yacht on Thursday April 10, 1913. The hull was made of steel, and although steam powered, it was rigged as a schooner. Length = 169 feet Beam = 22 feet Draft = 7.5 feet Although not fully commissioned, the launching was held at the yard of Charles L. Seabury & Co., Morris Heights into the Harlem River; and the yacht was enrolled in the New York Yacht Club. Sponsor was Mr. Archbold's daughter, Mrs. M. M. Van Buren. Although the third vessel of the same name owned by Mr. Archbold, the transom appears to bear the name "Vixen" and NOT "Vixen III" [ ref. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B01EFDF1730E233A... ]
