Actually, the title does appear to be abbreviated: Jap. for Japanese and Calif. for California.  It also appears to be a direct transcription from the original file card.  

Even if the original title had been offensive it would still be part of a historical document, and would hardly merit retroactive censorship, surely.
I was referencing the previous picture with the same title.  I think it was uploaded the week before this one.  LOC said they would retitle it.

Hello! The title in the catalog record was indeed copied from the original negative sleeve, in this instance, and not the negative itself. I'm afraid that our turnaround time for catalog record corrections has grown longer as we continue to collect data from our Flickr volunteers. I'll add this one to the list though. Thanks everyone for your time and patience!

When it is clear that Jap. (note the all important period) was intended as an abbreviation rather than a pejorative, what is there to correct?  

I may be wrong, but I don't believe the term 'Jap', uttered as a pejorative, was in wide currency until the Second World War, some thirty years after the photo was taken.  The catalog card may not have been filled out in 1910, but must nonetheless have been written up well before the war.  Incidentally, during the First World War, which of course took place not long after 1910, Japan was an ally of the US and Britain, a fact that renders it much less likely that the notes accompanying the image were contemptuous in meaning.

During the Second World War some very ugly racist propaganda directed at the Japanese was promulgated by the US Government and by news media.  The newspaper headlines, the Movietone News reels, the ubiquitous war propaganda posters all were ridden with the most offensive and racially charged imagery and wording.  As distasteful as these effusions of hatred are to us today, they are nonetheless historical documents.  They are reminders of aspects of American history that, while they do not make us proud, should not be ignored.  

Whereas the desperate GI fighting tooth and nail against the tough Japanese garrison of some shell-blasted atoll can be forgiven for stooping to slinging racial epithets with his bullets and grenades, the attitudes engendered in the comfortable US civil populace by wartime propaganda are much more unsettling (see Vonnegut).  The resultant ill treatment of Japanese-Americans, most especially the outright theft of their homes and possessions, was indeed a shameful chapter in US history.  

We know what attitudes pervaded US society during WW2, but what of the earlier decades of the 20th Century?  Did a photographer or a file clerk really evince contempt for the Japanese in 1910?  Or did one of those people innocently abbreviate the word Japanese to Jap., just as he or she employed Calif. for California?  This is not unimportant, and the file card in question, written upon by a long dead hand nearly a century ago, may provide us a window, however tiny, on the sensibilities of the time.  Let us not, please, run through the archives with a marker, blotting out anything that may just possibly give offense.  Anyone with a genuine interest in history wants to hear the whole story, good and bad, and not some polished official version.

Again, I draw your attention to the . (period); it is significant.

Thank you for the thought out response.  I too consider the times when thinking of these things.  

And I thank the LOC for these pictures and the desire they have to make them accurate.  I can't wait til the next Friday to see what we get next!

Yes, you are correct PN. As a rule, we do not change the language of original captions made by the creators of images in our collections. 

However, it would increase the image's "findability" in the Prints and Photographs Division's online catalog (PPOC), if the expanded title were to be included. As it is, a search for "japanese california," for example, will not return this photo among the results as these two words are not spelled out anywhere in the catalog record. 

Thank you very much for these points.

Lewis,

Thank-you for your response and your reassuring explanation of LOC policy.

Please reconsider retitling this photo to spell out Japanese. The abbreviation chosen is offensive to many and reverts to the dismissive terminology used during WWII and is out of place in this day and age. -- Found in a search. (?)

Thanks for understanding that no offense is intended. We retain the original title of a photograph as part of preserving the historical record. The Bain News Service photo titles are available from several sources—typed in the set of caption cards consulted while making the scans, hand-written on an older set of cards, and etched on the negatives themselves. Abbreviated spellings are common in each source, but, in this case, the sources differ. Transcribing the fuller title directly from the negative provides more information, and that source is now used.

George "KO" Brown was born George Contas in Sparta, Greece, in 1890. During his career as a middleweight boxer he fought over 100 bouts, mostly in the United States, but several in Australia. He was also known as Chicago "KO" Brown. It's a bit tricky to find information about him on the Internet, as a lightweight boxer named Valentine Brown (or Braun), who fought during the same period, was also often referred to in the sporting press as KO Brown or Knockout Brown, and the same nicknames were later applied to other boxers. George "KO" Brown does have a bout list at BoxRec. Among his opponents in the ring was Mike Gibbons, who is seen in this photo from the Bain collection.

"Mexican" Joe Rivers (1892-1957) was born Jose Ybarra, in Los Angeles, California. Despite his nickname, he was not a Mexican national but a fourth generation Californian. He was a lightweight boxer whose ring career lasted from 1910 to 1923. In 1912, he fought Ad Wolgast for the lightweight title. At the beginning of the thirteenth round, he and Wolgast both landed punches that sent the other down. Wolgast fell on top of Rivers, and referee Jack Welch helped Wolgast to his feet and began the count on Rivers. Welch declared Wolgast the winner by a technical knockout, in one of the most controversial decisions in the history of boxing. A video of the last thirty seconds of the famous "double knockdown" fight can be seen at this web page. Rivers had another shot at the lightweight title the next year when he fought Willie Ritchie, who had taken the title from Wolgast in November, 1912, but Ritchie knocked him out in the eleventh round. Here's the New York Times article about the 1913 Rivers-Ritchie fight. Following his ring career, Joe Rivers played bit parts in a few movies, and was technical adviser on one of them. Here's his IMDb page. Despite having made what was, for the time, a considerable fortune in the ring, Rivers' money eventually began to run out, and late in his life he was living in a windowless room in downtown Los Angeles. That's where L.A. Times reporter Frank Finch interviewed him in 1955, as told in this Times article from 1999, on the 42nd anniversary of Joe Rivers' death. Joe Rivers is buried at Calvary Cemetery in East Los Angeles.

I started an entry for him in Wikipedia: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Howard_Wilbert_Nowell Howard Wilbert Nowell (May 16, 1872 - 1940), was instructor in pathology at Boston University, and a pioneer cancer researcher. He had an early incorrect hypothesis for the cause of cancer, and an early treatment involving a serum derived from rabbits, that was touted as effective, but didn't survive rigorous testing. He was born in Merrimacport, Massachusetts on May 16, 1872. He graduated from Lyndon College, and the following year took a course at the Massachusetts College of Pharmacy and Health Sciences. He studied medicine at Boston University, and he graduated in 1911. He became an instructor of pathology at Boston University School of Medicine from 1911 to 1913, and professor at the same institution 1913 to 1915. He was pathologist at the Massachusetts Homeopathic Hospital 1911 to 1913 and special pathologist for the Evans Memorial for Preventive Medicine and Clinical Research. In 1913 he published a report of research work on cancer

Apparently, there were two barbers' strikes in the era covered by most of these Bain collection photographs. There was the Brooklyn barbers' strike of 1913, and there was the New York barbers' strike of 1914. Having searched the New York Times' accounts of the era, I suggest that the occasion shown in this photograph is Joseph J. Ettor speaking to the striking Brooklyn barbers at Union sqaure on May 16, 1913. Here is the New York Times account from printed the following day: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9F00E5DF143FE633A... In that account, it also states that, "There were not many mottoes displayed at the gathering, but one of those displayed read, "We were slaves. Now we want to be free." Another read: "The Industrial Workers of the World lead this strike. This means success."." This second slogan, "The Industrial Workers of the World lead this strike. This means success." can be made out on the sign at left of photograph just behind the column. I'll put a note on the pic highlighting that. For what little it is worth, here is the wikipedia bio of Joseph J. Ettor: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Ettor The photograph of Ettor at that wikipedia page also helps to identify him in this photograph.

Pince-nez type eyeglasses were the most popular eyewear in the USA, Canada and much of Europe during the period 1885 to 1920. A pince-nez had no arms or temples and clipped on the bridge of the nose. It was held in place by either spring powered nose guard grips in the fingerpiece type or a spring bridge with nose guard grips in the hoopspring or C bridge type. Properly fitted, a pince-nez remained securely attached to the bridge of the nose at all times and was very comfortable even during full time wear. Eyeglasses (pince-nez) and spectacles (glasses with temples) : were unisex then. The terms eyeglasses and spectacles had distinct meanings. The rimless type was the most popular and stylish for all ages. For soldiers,it was great for wear under a gas mask or goggles and army officials stated the a pince-nez was the ideal eyewear. 
See Pince-nez Renaissance blog/site the only place on the web or anywhere for very detailed,accurate info re: pince-nez.Click on table of contents. Many of the photos can be enlarged by clicking on them.

This statue of Thomas Jefferson by Austrian-born sculptor Karl Bitter (1867-1915) was unveiled on April 30, 1913. It is located in the Jefferson Memorial Building, home of the Missouri History Museum, 5700 Lindell Boulevard, St. Louis. The museum is on the site of the main entrance to the 1904 Louisiana Purchase Exposition, aka St. Louis World's Fair, and its construction was financed primarily by the proceeds of the fair. The fairgrounds are now the site of Forest Park.

The photo might have been taken at the time of the statue's unveiling, but might also have been published in newspapers two years later when, on April 10, 1915, sculptor Karl Bitter died of injuries received the previous night, when he had been struck by an automobile on Broadway in New York City after leaving the Metropolitan Opera House.

Originally known as the Pierpont Morgan Library, this institution is located at Madison Avenue and 36th Street in New York City. The Palladian style building was designed by architect Charles Follen McKim, and completed in 1906. The original entrance, as depicted in this photo, was at 33 E. 36th Street. The Morgan was made a public institution by the founder's son, J.P. Morgan Jr., in 1924. The building was declared a national historic landmark and added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1966. The Morgan Library & Museum web site.

Original comment: This Italianate brownstone house at the southeast corner of Madison Avenue and 37th Street in Manhattan was built in 1853 for Isaac N. Phelps of Phelps, Dodge & Company. The house was purchased by financier J.P. Morgan in 1904, as a home for his son J.P. Jr., but the property passed out of the family's ownership in 1945. In 1988, the house was purchased by the adjacent Morgan Library & Museum, and it has since been incorporated into that institution's campus. The former dining room is now one of the institution's dining facilities, called appropriately enough the Morgan Dining Room. Two other restored rooms on the ground floor now house the Morgan Shop. The Morgan Library & Museum web site.
Also good views here: www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2909004621/ www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/3239313168/ In both cases it is described as the home of J. P. Morgan, Jr.

This is J. Pierpont Morgan's House on the northeast corner of 219 Madison Avenue and E. 36th St. It was the first private residence in the city to be lighted by electricity. See digitalgallery.nypl.org/nypldigital/id?712325F. The address here says Park Avenue and 36th which is incorrect. Morgan Sr. lived here from 1880 to 1913, it was torn down in 1928. The house that Phelps built (copper mining tycoon) was the southeast corner of 229-231 Madison Avenue and E. 37th St. (J.P'Jack' Morgan Jr.'s house) which had in 1904, 45 rooms, 22 fireplaces and 12 bathrooms. The two houses and the Morgan Library were connected by underground passageways.

Actually, I think you were both right.     It's my understanding that all three freestanding brownstone houses on that side of Madison Avenue between 36th and 37th were built by the Phelps family, and at first they were identical to each other.     All three were remodeled to varying degrees  over the years, but they were clearly built using the same basic plans and materials      The New York Times archives has photos of the deconstruction of the middle house - which at that time was generally known as the Dodge Mansion -  and by viewing the three buildings together,  their similarities become very obvious.    The first thing Morgan Senior did after buying his  own house was to move the entrance stoop.    The front doors of all three homes were originally located on Madison Ave, but Morgan replaced his home's original stoop with the large rounded bay (that's seen in the above photo) and placed this new entrance on 36th St..   He also hired the Herter Brothers to remodel and redecorate the interiors.     The Dodge Mansion, at the time of its demolition at least, had a central entrance with rounded bays on either side of it, and the various changes made to Jack Morgan's house on the corner of 37th St. are pretty easy to spot when comparing it to his father's original house.

I assume they're probably calling this the "MRS. J.P. Morgan House" because the picture above was taken after Morgan's death in 1913 but while Fanny Morgan was still using the place as her city residence.    She really preferred their country place, Cragston, but nobody in the Morgan's set would think of living in the country year-round, not in those days.

According to Frederick Lewis Allen who wrote, "the great Pierpont Morgan" in 1948 the three Dodge-Phelps houses were built in the 1850's on the East side of Madison Ave. between between thirty-sixth and thirty-seventh streets. All three brownstone houses had "ample" gardens behind them".  In 1880 he bought the southernmost of the three houses-the one at the corner of Thirty-sixth which had originally belonged to Issac N. Phleps. It stood where the white marble annex of the Morgan Library now stands and "roughly resembled the remaining brownstone house at the corner of Madison and Thirty-seventh- which in 1948 was the sole survivor of that group of houses".
I have since run across this postcard image taken while all three of the original Dodge-Phelps houses were still standing. farm3.staticflickr.com/2807/13201523223_3a0bc51e55_o.jpg

^ These three houses were built in 1854, 1) by Isaac N. Phelps, on the corner of Thirty-seventh Street; 2) John Jay Phelps, on the corner of Thirty-sixth Street; and 3) William E. Dodge (who married Melissa Phelps, daughter of Anson Greene Phelps), in the middle. At that time Madison Avenue extended only to Forty-second Street. Isaac Newton Phelps was a banker and nothing to do with Phelps Dodge. His son in law, Anson Phelps Stokes was and so was next door William E Dodge. Anson's son was architect Isaac newton Phelps Stokes and he was born in 229 Madison Avenue. Anson and his wife Helen went on to own 229 and sold it to Morgan. See: archive.org/stream/stokesrecordsnot03instok#page/n57/mode...
Thanks for posting that.   It's the best image I've seen of the three houses all together and still looking this similar too.

The top attic floor of 229/231 Madison Avenue was added 1888 and the size of the house doubled by architect R H Robertson, so if you can find a picture without the added floor it would be interesting.

"N.Y. May Day Parade Strikers' children from Paterson.", it reads. This relates to the Paterson Silk Strike of 1913, and this therefore is of course May 01, 1913. Here is a reference in a book to the New York May Day Parade of 1913: books.google.com.au/books?id=8oXpyXXavIkC&pg=PA79&... Here's the wikipedia entry on the strike: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paterson_Silk_Strike_of_1913 And from the New York Times of May 02, 1913: " It was a strikeless May Day for New York, and the paraders had to import some 110 children of Paterson silk strikers from New Jersey to give embodiment to the woes of the workers." and "The big auto labeled "Children of Paterson Strikers" in great red letters reached Union Square at 4:10 o'clock, and was greeted with the greatest burst of cheering of the day." [ ref. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9505E7DB103BE633A... ] I don't know if this photograph was taken in Union Square. Perhaps some of you New Yorkers can help with that one.

By comparison with the newly uploaded photograph [ www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/3295494976/ ] which was taken in Union Square on May Day 1913, we can now say that this photograph too was taken when the Stirkers' children arrived in Union Square. I'm tagging this and some other associated photographs with "May Day 1913" to make them easier to find.

This was taken at the north end of Union Square. The building on the left rear is 200 Park Avenue South (perhaps 4th Avenue when the picture was taken). The upper right hand corner of the picture seems to have a date written on a stamp. There was a major commotion at the 1912 May Day celebration, at the north end of Union Square, where the American flag was ripped down from the speaker's platform (perhaps to the right of the picture) and trampled. A woman in the crowd eventually dusted the flag off and folded it on her arm. There is an American flag in the right center of the picture, but there isn't enough information in the picture for me to definitely place it in 1912. For the full NYT account of the 1912 event see: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A05E4DD153CE633A...
This photo is of the 1913 May Day rally, according to the date on the Bain News Agency's sticker, in the upper right hand corner.

William Snyder, was the head keeper in the Central Park Zoo in Manhattan. He is mentioned in this article: William Snyder, head keeper in the Central Park Zoo, undertook yesterday morning to transfer eight big African pythons from a box to a small cage. Louis F. La Roche, a representative of Park Comsioner Stover, and Thomas Brady, a painter, helped him. The snakes had been put in the box while their old quarters were being done over, and they had not been fed as frequently as usual because of this change. Source: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9906E3DB133BE633A... Stover must be the Parks Commissioner Charles B. Stover. He was thought to be dead in 1913 in Delaware when a body resembling him was found: Friends of Park Commissioner Charles B. Stover were much alarmed last night when dispatches from Wilmington, Del., said that in a body found in the Christiana River, near the shipyard of the American Car and Foundry Company there, Coroner John T. Spring of Wilmington reported that he recognized striking resemblance to Mr. Stover, whose whereabouts have not been known for some time. Source: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9F0DEED91E3BE633A... Augustus Thomas (January 8, 1857 – August 12, 1934) was an American playwright, born in St. Louis, Missouri. The son of a doctor, he worked a number of jobs including a page in the 41st Congress, studying law and gaining some practical railway work experience before he turned to journalism and became editor of the Kansas City Mirror in 1889. Thomas had been writing since his teens when he wrote plays and even organized a small theatrical touring company. Source: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Augustus_Thomas

Clementine Helene Dufau 1869 - 1937
Dufau, Clémentine Hélène (1869-1937)

Awards from the Salon, Bashkirtseff prize, 1895; medal third class, 1897; traveling purse, 1898; medal second class, 1902; Hors Concours; silver medal, Paris Exposition, 1900. Picture in the Luxembourg, 1902. Member of the Société des Artistes Français and of the Società Heleno Latina, Rome. Born at Quinsac (Gironde).

Studies made at Julian Academy, under Bouguereau and Robert-Fleury. Mlle. Dufau calls her works illustrations and posters, and gives the following as the principal examples:
"Fils des Mariniers," in Museum of Cognac; "Rhythme," "Dryades," "Automne," a study, Manzi collection; "Espagne," "Été," Behourd collection; "Automne," Gallery of the Luxembourg. The latter is a decorative work of rare interest. At the Salon of 1903 Mlle. Dufau exhibited two works—"La grande Voix" and "Une Partie de Pelotte, au Pays basque." The latter was purchased by the Government, and will be hung in the Luxembourg.

Anna Howard Shaw (February 14, 1847 – July 2, 1919) was a leader of the women's suffrage movement in the United States. She was also a physician and the first ordained female Methodist minister in the United States. Source: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anna_Shaw Florence Jaffray "Daisy" Harriman (July 21, 1870 – August 31, 1967) was an American socialite, suffragist, social reformer, organizer, and later, a courageous diplomat. “She led one of the suffrage parades down Fifth Avenue, worked on campaigns on child labor and safe milk and, as minister to Norway in World War II, organized evacuation efforts while hiding in a forest from the Nazi invasion.” In her ninety-second year, U.S. President John F. Kennedy honored her by awarding her the first “Citation of Merit for Distinguished Service.” She often found herself in the middle of historic events. As she stated, “I think nobody can deny that I have always had through sheer luck. . . a box seat at the America of my times.” Source: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Florence_Jaffray_Harriman The photographer was fooled by the name on the banner she was carrying. Florence Jaffray "Daisy" Harriman (July 21, 1870 – August 31, 1967) was an American socialite, suffragist, social reformer, organizer, and later, a courageous diplomat. “She led one of the suffrage parades down Fifth Avenue, worked on campaigns on child labor and safe milk and, as minister to Norway in World War II, organized evacuation efforts while hiding in a forest from the Nazi invasion. "In her ninety-second year, U.S. President John F. Kennedy honored her by awarding her the first “Citation of Merit for Distinguished Service.” She often found herself in the middle of historic events. As she stated, “I think nobody can deny that I have always had through sheer luck. . . a box seat at the America of my times.” Source: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Florence_Jaffray_Harriman

Of course the image is flipped.  Daguerreotypes are direct positive images, there is no negative.  You see what the lens sees, the image is reversed and upside down.  Look at the image on the ground glass of a view camera and you will see what the daguerreotype saw.  Sometimes this was corrected with the use  of a prism or mirror, but more often not.

"None of his predecessors did anything remotely close to what Lincoln did in terms of suspending human rights."

None of his predecessors were dealing with a civil war. The idea of business as usual, in a time when a major chunk of the country was trying to secede, violating the Union? Ridiculous.

Funny how people can't understand that in times of war, normal "rights" are removed. It's man against man, trying to take your LIFE -- how's that for a right removed? It's not a civilized thing, war. It totally abrogates the social contract and the most fundamental moral codes. This idea that there's an honorable way to conduct wars is asinine and shameful. It's what allows us to calmly enter into them in the first place, what allows us to be genuinely surprised that the whole endeavor isn't a neatly conducted game ... that makes it possible for anyone to be shocked that "civilians" are often put in harm's way. What? Is the horrid intent of war not clear? Does anyone think the human damage can really be contained to the poor pawns in uniform? Or that doing so would make the killing in any sense more morally just? Jesus help us, people are stupid. There are times when war is called for. But if you believe that, and enter into it, don't have on blinders.

By the way, the Union wasn't fighting to end slavery. The Union was fighting because those who wanted to preserve and spread the right to enslave, wanted to secede. The Union wanted the vast wealth of the natural resources in the south. They wanted to keep the contiguous land mass united. They couched it in terms of slavery, at times, because those were the terms by which secession was made. Yes, 18 months into the War, an emancipation proclamation was floated -- but emancipation would never have been a reason for war, on its own. Well, not from the Union offensive stance.

"None of his predecessors were dealing with a civil war. The idea of business as usual, in a time when a major chunk of the country was trying to secede, violating the Union? Ridiculous." In the war of 1812, foreign troops attacked and occupied Washington DC, setting the white house and Capitol on fire. The war wasn't on as large a scale as the civil war, but the idea that Lincoln was alone in facing an existential threat to the Union is unfounded. The revolutionary war itself was an existential threat to nationhood itself, and the people who fought it wrote the very provisions that Lincoln flaunted. "The idea of business as usual, in a time when a major chunk of the country was trying to secede, violating the Union? Ridiculous." nobody is talking about "business as usual". martial law and the suspension of habeus corpus happens often in times of war, when the mechanisms of civil justice are often unavailable. If there's no functioning judiciary in an area of conflict, such chaos is inevitable and cruder methods of maintaining order are understandable. Lincoln's issue was that he suspended habeus corpus in areas with functional courts, well within union territory. he essentially short circuited a functional judicial system. was this necessary? i'm not sure. maybe. but it was certainly a power grab and set a precedent for a consolidation of executive power that continues to this day.

I said none of his predecessors faced a *civil* war.

As for his tactics re the judicial system -- the thrust of my comment was meant to say, if killing is okay, why should other rights be safe? To pretend any other kinds of rights should be carefully handled, if the right to life is being systematically taken away, is a philosophically absurd notion. That we can both have a designated time of killing those with whom we do not agree, and parade about like idiots, keeping to the letter of all other man-made laws -- that's what allows such brutality to happen, the idea that when we're engaging in the absolute antithesis of our reason for being (sustenance of life) by killing each other, we can still be "civilized" and orderly. Putting war in a context like that -- even expecting it -- means one is not possibly grasping how very wrong it is to kill, as if the killing is less of a transgression than imprisonment or loss of privacy, or even torture.

And again, I don't think all war is wrong. But understand that it is utterly anti-social, anti-life, anti-civility. To expect otherwise is to be naive, and disappointed. Just because during some wars we *have* maintained levels of continuity of our governmental systems, and maintained the everyday workings of the social contract, doesn't impress me as good. It impresses me as sick, that we were able to compartmentalize a very animalistic way of settling differences. Again -- a way sometimes necessary, but not to be confused with business as usual.

"ALL is "fair" in war. If killing is okay, nothing is safe." but that has no bearing on how you treat you own citizens in times of war. in war, the other side is the enemy, not your own people. if you have traitors in your midst, that can be established fairly, by a functioning judiciary. another more modern example, britain survived imminent invasion and mass bombing without suspending habeus corpus in WWII.

We weren't invaded. It was in our midst, it was our own people, and not on clear-cut lines. Within the same households, both north and south, there was division. It would have been chaos to try to take the time to figure out who was or was not a traitor, by the long process of the law. You do your best with information at hand, when quick decisions must be made -- just as I'm sure there were men with guns on fields, unable to tell for sure who was the enemy. But you can't just stand there, and wait to figure it out. Again, being in the midst of a war isn't a good place to be.

It seems to me we've turned war into a codified, acceptable means of conflict resolution, by giving it rules and regulations in and of itself, and in seeking to continue all non-wartime rules and regulations just as they are in peacetime. We make it seem as if "war" is just part of the bigger picture, something that stands by itself, that shouldn't upset the normal fabric of life. I don't think that makes sense, morally or practically.

As a last point, since I come off sounding totally anti-war -- I'll reiterate that at times, I think it's called for. But that if it is, it should be understood, nothing and no one is safe. And again, they oughtn't be. If it's okay for anyone to die, than it should be reason enough for everyone to die -- it should only be done for reasons of survival in the first place, where your military and people would die anyway, if you didn't engage (i.e. your most basic resources are imminently threatened, your lives are directly threatened).

"We weren't invaded. It was in our midst, it was our own people, and not on clear-cut lines. Within the same households, both north and south, there was division." same with the revolutionary war, which was fought by the people who wrote the constitution that Lincoln flaunted. "It seems to me we've turned war into a codified, acceptable means of conflict resolution, by giving it rules and regulations in and of itself, and in seeking to continue all non-wartime rules and regulations just as they are in peacetime." that's because the law protects human rights, which we should endeavour to protect at all times, especially in wartime. it isn't about turning war into an acceptable means of conflict resolution, it's about understanding that rights are inalienable, not privileges to be whisked away simply because there's a war on.

To think that human rights exist somehow a priori, that they persist in a vacuum, or that they shall endure without a host nation is terminally naive. They are merely ideals, and not at all immutable, given form or verse simply by those in concert willing to make difficult choices to, above all else, protect themselves from material harm.

I would assert further that idealism is at its heart a peacetime proposition, a luxury borne of leisure, hurled so loosely in philosophical corridors. And that it is often aimed, ironically enough, at the warrior ilk that keeps the barbarians at bay, such that those discussions, however noble in speculation, may persist, is among the grander ironies.
And whilst I rant from those aforementioned corridors of leisure and food aplenty, I am curious: for those who would brand Lincoln a tyrant, who among the American pantheon do you admire?

Striatic,

We disagree about the Civil War being comparable to the Revolutionary War.

And as far as I see it, the law doesn't protect human rights. The law protects civil order. It's possible to do so in a way that hinders human rights, in fact. Our system is not one that does so, it's true that we seek to optimize human rights in the pursuit and maintenance of peace. But in a time of war, when one feels the populace is threatened, it may be that maintaining civil order and the safety of the majority, means there will be some whose human rights will be compromised. Not nice? Well, don't have a war. 

Lincoln didn't randomly take away rights of his own citizens. It seems he believed himself unable to secure the safety of the greater number, without suspending habeas corpus. As I understand it, he wasn't happy to act outside of the Constitutional provisions, he believed it to be a genuinely necessary matter of expediency. And in the context, I don't think it can be well argued that he was wrong. The men he sought to snare were not "his own," they were the enemy, among his own. I made the analogy above, I'll make it again: if you are in a battle, and you are going to judge the entire success in terms of losses by friendly fire, you ought not be in the battle in the first place. If you aren't ready to sacrifice yourselves a bit to quash the opponent, the opponent wasn't worth fighting. Lincoln believed the Union was worth preserving. He was in the fight to win. He sacrificed the lives of many, many men to do so. Did the possibility that a few of the suspected traitors he imprisoned and/or executed were innocent, weigh heavily on his mind? I've no idea. It had to have been balanced by the responsibility he felt to the entire Union, acknowledging the risk that real traitors would have posed to a great number of men.

It's not an exact science, this playing about with morality. That's what I'm saying -- once you're in a war, it's not as black and white as it is in peacetime. It's not that a leader has carte blanche to transgress the status quo altogether, but the truth is, the worst transgression against human rights is already in play: the systematic killing of others. Ostensibly, it is done for a "just" reason -- anyway, one you consider worth the sacrifice of others. And so Lincoln did, on the battlefield, and possibly, in the courtroom.

you're defending Lincoln by saying that rights are luxuries. unbelievable.

saying that America's constitutional ideals were born of leisure and peace is also unbelievable.

Make no mistake, the nations themselves which are the safe havens in which those ideals best flourish are forged of blood and iron. In this way, the principles that guide said founding necessarily precede it. If these notions are conceived, authored, embraced or otherwise beforehand, it is the calm before the storm that lays witness to their genesis. How then can you so vehemently rebuke the premise that - regardless of the approaching storm clouds, and in spite of the semantics - those ideals owe to the reflection and discourse afforded as a luxury of peacetime?

reflection and discourse are not "luxuries of peacetime". reflection and discourse are what human beings *do*. we are communicative creatures. we also fight each other over differences, but that is no more or less important to our liberty and security than our ability to find mutual interests and sustain prosperity through reflection and discourse.

sometimes that discourse falls apart and people have to die to defend their interests, but we don't all live with knives at each others throats as you seem to insist.

reflection and discourse are necessary implements of building mutual understanding and shared prosperity, not "goodies" you get after stabbing or shooting a bunch of people.

"that's because the law protects human rights, which we should endeavour to protect at all times, especially in wartime... it's about understanding that rights are inalienable, not privileges to be whisked away simply because there's a war on. " Just as a matter of accounting, what percentage of the Earth's billions enjoy these "inalienable" rights? Certainly not half - do you think one third? One fourth? It's starting to sound more like a privilege than a birthright to me.

I never said rights are luxuries. I said that if you're on board with taking away the most basic of human rights (If you accept that killing is an acceptable tool for conflict resolution), it seems a curious hypocrisy to worry about any other human right. That Lincoln, believing he was mitigating loss of life for many, made the difficult decision to *possibly* take the liberty or even life of one or two innocents. But I gather you would rather he had stood on principle. Principle that would have undoubtedly resulted in traitors taking action that mortally endangered thousands, left free many foul quislings, and yes, avoided harm to a few men falsely accused. In that time of war, Lincoln apparently didn't feel he had the luxury to pursue to its bitter end a principle that in peacetime it would have been unthinkable to transgress. He considered the protection of the majority of his people, not the few, which seems to me eminently responsible. A difficult choice, made in an extraordinary time in our history.

"I never said rights are luxuries."

no. you merely thought that the sentiment was "beautifully stated".

Likewise, does your apparent distaste at conceding that the discourse of ideologues flourishes during periods of peace-and-plenty somehow suggest that they are instead birthed of the toils of war? And perhaps even by the warriors themselves, on battlefields seldom of their own choosing, and not the scholars and whitebeards that debate endlessly, in their marble halls, far from the reach of the enemy?

Then, I suppose, as goes the war, so too then the ideals? 

Ergo, the side with the more able soldiers, the more capable generals, and the greater resources gets to pick which set of lofty ideals shall dominate after peace is established - or imposed. If these really are inalienable rights, and not subjective privileges simply afforded the victorious, then it seems curious and moreover cruel that they often hinge on something so fickle as a harsh winter or an impassible strait! 
 
How precarious, then, these rights that Providence anoints but seldom appoints!

And, of course, when push does come to shove, "stabbing and shooting" are of course more noble than listening in on fifty people's phone calls. Better to just kill them, rather than usurp anyone's "rights" - right? And in the name of all that is holy, please don't play that Britn*y Spears music too loud: that wouldn't be nice.

No, I am saying (I won't speak for PopKulture) that if you do not have peace, relative prosperity, and stability, you aren't going to be able to sit around and wax rhapsodic about philosophic ideals, as we are doing now. That it is a luxury to have the time and lack of danger all about, or crop to harvest or else starvation is imminent, so that one can live the life of the mind and banter semantics about "freedom" and "human rights."

And the rights themselves seem to follow as a luxury, because if you don't have time or money to sit about debating with other like-minded men at Fraunces Tavern about how mean it is for the Crown to tax you without representation, then you aren't going to go after those rights, are you? And today, the people working in sweatshops in SE Asia aren't enacting social and political change, because they're too damn busy breaking their backs from dawn til dusk. I think they would consider some of the political rights we enjoy as a luxury, and certainly the time to sit at laptop computers pontificating about the finer points of ethics, an overwhelming luxury.

"no. you merely thought that the sentiment was "beautifully stated". He didn't say anything about rights, in the statement I reacted to. And I may not have been in agreement with his thinking -- I said it was beautifully stated, complimenting his writing. I happen to agree with him, however. It is absolutely true that the ideals with which the Constitution are imbued, do not stand alone as abstract truths. Now, he did go on to say that "idealism is a peacetime proposition." So it is. The founders, if you'd like to focus on them, did all their pre-revolution idealizing in a very peaceful environment. A stable one. Any pre-revolutionary violence was by the fomentation of those unhappy with the British rule, and it was minor. I don't disagree with what they did, but please -- they were all of them incredibly elite, wealthy, leisure-class men. Jefferson, Franklin et al. were of course industrious in many ways ... also a reflection of their utter financial freedom, and a peaceful environment. They were able to sit around, conceiving of political philosophy, scientific and agrarian experimentation, etc. Sounds like a luxurious life to me.

So markedly right, Julia. I hold all of the aforementioned in utter esteem, by the way, for making the difficult choices they made. 

The fact remains that this proverbial "calm before the storm" coincided with a relatively peaceful and prosperous time.

Yes ... and funny, for as apparently holy as some consider them, or anyway, their writings, they certainly did suspend a very important human right, when they decided that their right to the pursuit of happiness warranted butchering the Redcoats, eh? (Not that the British wouldn't -- and didn't -- do the same, to try to secure *their* interests.) Granted, like you, I'm glad they did, and that they prevailed. But as far as I can tell, we're all of us willing to suspend our lofty ideals and others' inalienable rights, in the process of securing our inalienable rights. That's human nature, it seems to me.

"depends on what you mean by 'enjoy'." You choose. Tell us what totalitarian regime makes the grade, what dictator makes the cut-off, what kingdom receives high marks. I'm sincerely curious. I fully feel it goes a long way to resolving the almost arbitrary and admittedly semantic rights v. privilege question. Likewise, as we've certainly seen here, criticism is by no means a scarce commodity. I fully admire Lincoln. I admit it. His presidency coincided with one of the most difficult periods in our history. I petition again, with the same curiosity - who do you admire?

Yes! Exactly! They would all have been hanged as traitors ... "reflection and discourse" ARE "goodies" you get after stabbing or shooting a bunch of people!! There are no abstract rights, without sponsorship -- not in practice, anyway. The rights that prevail are certainly part of the spoils enjoyed by the victorious. Do you think that the U.S. would be defined by a Judeo-Christian ethical spirit, if the Native Americans had successfully defended their land? What if Europeans had been allowed to live here, but not as a dominating force ... don't you think the ethical code that would characterize our government would have more to do with some synthesis of the idea of the divine held by the indigenous Americans? Across the globe, people fight to the death for the right not just to live by their own set of beliefs, but to live without having to be anywhere near anyone that doesn't believe as they do. It seems to me they fight so that they can reflect and discourse on their own terms, and no one else's. To them, ideology *is* a commodity -- the supremacy of which, can be determined by violence. I'm being a little difficult -- I do see that you're saying that the right to actually discuss and reflect is a human right not bartered by war. That's sort of true, but just keep in mind ... Sitting at the head of the "reflection and discourse" table are those with political or economic power. For better or worse, they set the agenda, and the collective values of a government or educational system, will reflect what they consider most important. Just like it did at the Constitutional Conventions. PS You think the pursuit of happiness, with all that implies, was used as a glib rejoinder? Not at all. I'll put it this way -- "when they decided that their right to liberty warranted butchering the redcoats." Does that sound like a right more worth taking someone's life for? Don't be afraid to say so, if it is. Jesus, if you believe SOME rights are worth dying for, then where was Lincoln wrong? Was he not sacrificing lives (who cares on what side -- they were all human beings) for an ideal he held sacred? Or is it that *you* are the arbiter of what constitutes a Just War? Perhaps it isn't Lincoln's actions that bother you, but that he did them to support an economic and political war, not one about ultimate Human Rights? Gah.

” and you're avoiding the point. if rights, discourse and reflection are what keep us from murdering each other over absolutely every issue that crops up, how can they be "luxuries"? they're necessities.” Whoa! I never said “rights” had anything to do with keeping us from murdering each other. That little measure of co-existence owes to our individual guiding principles and ethics in addition to the proscriptions - and penalties - of the civil law, and moreover, at its heart, our innate fear that we may, in the process of attempting said murder, fail and invite mortal harm instead upon ourselves! It’s that animal instinct of self-preservation that helps us steer clear of dire situations like that, not rights. Now, admittedly, thoughtful reflection and discourse are valuable tools in avoiding mortal conflict once disagreement and resentment fester. At the negotiation table, however, where compromise is the watchword by which most conflicts are mitigated, then aren’t those so-called inalienable rights by definition compromised in the process, at least for someone? Take, for example, something as commonplace as the peaceful exchange between dissimilar nations of a commodity like oil. Fleets of tankers leave Middle Eastern shores on an almost daily basis, and we happily send them a tidy bouquet of promissory debt and everyone’s happy. Mostly. In the case of the S*udis, we periodically take our seat at an oaken table in lavish staterooms, armed with our material needs, our multicultural relativism, and our ability-forged-of-necessity to look the other way, and we’re able to initiate and perpetuate this peaceable exchange. Now, where do the ol’ inalienable rights come into play again?? I’m sorry – is this where noble civility and that dose of compromise I mentioned above conspire to ignore said rights? I mean, we certainly get to talk about it enough. We’ve gone back and forth many times here already, and enjoyably (admit it) at that, brandishing about philosophical points like so many ping pong balls. We’ve got the leisure time, the electricity, the connectivity, and actual hardware and so on to make it all happen. I would submit to you, that I bet if we even get hungry, there’s food in the refrigerator! (Pretty nice luxury.) Well, I’m sorry now to burst the proverbial bubble I’ve so recently constructed, but we’ve come away from that table with our rights intact, sure… we do it almost everyday. And what are those rights again? And where are those same rights for the S*udi woman that wants to – I don’t know - hop in her car and take a spin over to the local university where she can learn the language and maybe take a few classes in western philosophy, thereby enabling her to jump right on in on our philosophical musings? They’re not hers. We didn’t even bring them to the table. No one did. That’s reality, subjective and indifferent. So regarding the mere existence of inalienable rights, we therefore owe an enormous debt of gratitude and awe to a system that even enables us to think thus!!

Such reasoning was exactly what caused the founders to take up arms against the British -- an imminent threat to their ideals, and by extension, their survival. Anyone who is looking at a 200 year old image of anything and  not appreciating that fact alone is on the wrong website. We are photographers here. We're sharing our eyes to the world with everyone so that they might have a larger understanding, a moment of inspiration, a connection, or a rejection. But, even if it is a rejection, this community is generally supportive, constructive, or silent. We're photographers here - not politicians.  Can you imagine if you posted a photograph that anyone would care at all about in 200 years, regardless of subject matter? Politics don't belong here.

It is an amazing photograph. But it wasn't taken back in 1847 as a celebration of photography, nor is it shared here as such. It was significant then as it is significant now: as a piece of material history, specifically important because of the subject. I have discovered in the last four years here that flickr is not merely a place to discuss photography. Many of us also routinely discuss issues or feelings that are inspired by the photographs we see posted. Taking part in those discussions is completely voluntary. In this case, the discussion was prompted by an image of a politician; it was absolutely topical. And I disagree -- we are all politicians, or so Solon intended: we live in a democracy, where it is our right (some might say our responsibility) to actively discuss our political beliefs. One needn't take advantage of that freedom, or fulfill that responsibility, but I don't think it is appropriate to tell others to refrain from such interaction.

Hannibal Hamlin "Lincoln's Frustrated Vice President" August 27, 1809 - July 4, 1891 Abraham Lincoln's first vice president, Hannibal Hamlin, was a distinguished New England politician who served six terms in the Maine legislature (1836-40 and 1847); represented his state in the House of Representatives for two terms; and interrupted his second term in the U.S. Senate in 1857 to serve as governor of Maine, a position he soon resigned to re-enter the Senate. Hamlin was a Democrat until 1856, when he broke with the party over the Kansas-Nebraska Act and joined the Republican party. When Lincoln won the Republican presidential nomination at the convention held at the Wigwam in Chicago on May 8, 1860, party leaders sought a vice-presidential candidate who would balance the ticket. Hannibal Hamlin seemed to be a good choice. A former Democrat with antislavery sentiments, he was geographically desirable since he came from a northeastern state. Hamlin had not wanted the vice presidency. Having traded his influential Senate seat for a traditionally powerless office, he hoped to be assigned some important function in the Lincoln government. Although the president listened to his views, which included his urging the issuance of the Emancipation Proclamation and the enlisting of free blacks in the army, Hamlin was relegated to the background. Hamlin resented his idleness, but he did not want to be replaced as vice president. When the president and his advisors decided it would be politically expedient to name Andrew Johnson, military governor of Tennessee, to the vice-presidential spot in 1864, Hamlin was again disappointed. After his vice presidency, Hamlin was collector of customs for the port of Boston, served again in the Senate (1869-81), and concluded his public career by serving as minister to Spain (1881-82) during the Arthur administration. He died suddenly on July 4, 1891, at his club in Bangor. Fascinating Fact: Frustrated by his lack of meaningful work while vice president, Hamlin enlisted as a private in the Maine Coast Guard and invoked public criticism by taking his place among the ranks during the 1864 summer encampment at Kittery. civilwar.bluegrass.net/PoliticsAndPoliticians/hannibalham...

The reason there are mostly men in the photo is that mostly men worked in Washington.  Secretaries in Washington were men.  Don't forget, women did not have the right to vote back then.  Women stayed home for the most part and took care of the family.  Fixing meals and washing and mending clothing by HAND was quite a chore.  There was no sitting around fiddling on the computer or watching the tube.  If you were a woman out and about by yourself in the city, you probably would have been considered a "hussy" by most people.  It was a hard life being a woman in the 1860s unless you happened to live in a wealthy family that had servants.

I only wonder why this photo is flipped.
When flipped horizontal, it reads .......
 " lincoln's funeral " written on the top.

Just wondering ~

The photo, as presented here, is correctly oriented.  If you look at one of the archival TIFFs on the LOC website, which have much higher resolution, you can see several signs on the buildings; they're not flipped.

Here's the explanation: Remember that this is a glass plate negative; it's simply a big, clear glass shelf with photographic emulsion coated on it.  (The Victorians didn't have the plastics used in modern "film"; the best they could do was clunky, fragile glass.)  So, the unknown archivist who wrote "lincoln's funeral" simply wrote it on the wrong side of the plate, so that it came out backward when printed.  It didn't really matter, since the text was intended to be cropped out of prints anyway.  It was just there as an indexing aid.

I've seen photos of Robert Lincoln's two daughters as older adults.  They both had Marfan Syndrome, a Lincoln family genetic inheritance.  In the photos I saw, they were both wearing 'Body Aids,' the earliest electric-powered prototypes of wearable high-powered hearing aids.  Congenital hearing loss is one of the features of Marfan Syndrome.

One wonders what Mrs. William Howard Taft -- first lady, wife of the Republican President of the U. S. -- was doing at the Democratic National Convention?

Okay, I found the answer in this paragraph from her bio as first lady:
"In July 1912, Nellie Taft again broke precedent when she attended the National Democratic Convention in Baltimore, becoming not only the first incumbent First Lady to attend a convention, but the only one to ever attend that of the opposition party. Although Taft was defeated by Democrat Woodrow Wilson, it was a partial success to Nellie Taft: her ambition as Election Day neared was to see Roosevelt defeated. The day before she left the White House, Nellie Taft's genuine view on suffrage made itself known: she ascended to a prominent place on a grandstand to review a parade of suffragists and encourage their demand of the incoming president to support a woman's right to vote."

Wilhelm Heinrich Benignus (1861–1931) was a German writer (according to de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liste_deutschsprachiger_Schriftstel...) "Hermann Wilhelm Heinrich Benignus, born on February 17, 1861 in Heilbronn, enrolled as an ordinary student at the Stuttgart Technical High School. He came to America in 1882. The Interstate Commerce Commission of the United States. On the top of the photo are names of the men, from left to right: Meyer Harlan Clements Clark Prouty McChord Marble According to the All Commissioners List, the men, their time on the commission, and home state are: James S. Harlan 1906-1918 IL Charles C. McChord 1910-1926 KY Balthasar H. Meyer 1910-1939 MI John Hobart Marble 1913 CA Edgar E. Clark 1906-1921 IA Charles A. Prouty 1896-1914 VT Judson C. Clements 1892-1917 GA This photo was take between March 10 and November 20, 1913. According to the All Commissioners List, the photo's date must be in 1913 because Marble only served one year. This is confirmed in the New York Times, Novemeber 22 1913 page 1, which describes the sudden death of Marble. The date of his appointment to the commission was March 10, 1913. Possibly this photo is from soon after March 10, when Marble and Clark were appointed to the commission. Incidentally, on page 9 of the August 14, 1915 New York Times, it is described that Marble replaced Franklin Knight Lane when he became Secretary of the Interior, and Marble was succeeded by Silas W. Smith after death. Neither of these men are photographed, strengthening the case for March 10 to November 20 1913 as the date. Marble had served as attorney and secretary for the commission before being appointed as commissioner, so this extra step seems important.
My suspicion is confirmed in the bottom left of the photo: very faintly written is "3/15/13".  March 15th, 1913.
Impressive research ^^

"In the winter of 1917-18 [Reid] made a semi-official speaking tour of the United States of America for the war effort, but became ill at St Louis in February and again in April after returning to London. In July he took part in a debate on Irish affairs, moving an important amendment to defuse a motion condemning the government's policy. Rafael Reyes Prieto (December 5, 1849, Santa Rosa de Viterbo, Boyacá, Colombia – February 18, 1921, Bogotá) was commander in chief of the Colombian National Army and President of Colombia (1904-1909). In his years as president he received money from the United States as part of the indemnity for Panama. This brought years of progress to Colombia but clearly the North American country got more profit from the Panama Canal. After being president Reyes was exiled from Colombia, after suffering several attempts to kill him. Source: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rafael_Reyes James Martin Eder (June 24, 1838 – December 26, 1921), known in Colombia as Santiago Martín Eder Kaiser, or simply don Santiago Eder, is considered the pioneer of the sugar industry in Colombia, and is widely recognized as one of Colombia's leading 19th century industrial pioneers. Source: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Martin_Eder

4/21/13 is the date written. At this time, the California legislature was considering a large number of anti-Japanese measures. According to books.google.com/books?id=QZg6Ft_jvJ0C&pg=RA1-PA257&a... [Japanese American History By Brian Niiya] "word of the bill [that became the California Alien Land Law) reached Japan and segments of the population there called for War with the United States. On April 22, President [Woodrow] Wilson sent telegrams to Governor Johnson and the legislature calling for a non-discriminatory land bill that did not single out Japanese immigrants. Despite an eleventh hour trip to California by Secretary of State William Jennings Bryan, the Alien Land Law was overwhelmingly passed by both halves of the legislature and signed by Johnson on May 17, 1913, to become effective on August 10."

**********************************************************************
HISTORY OF THE OLD AMERICANA PHOTOS

This image comes from the George Grantham Bain Collection which represents one of America's earliest news picture agencies. The collection richly documents sports events, theater, celebrities, crime, strikes, disasters, political activities including the woman suffrage campaign, conventions and public celebrations. The photographs Bain produced and gathered for distribution through his news service were worldwide in their coverage, but there was a special emphasis on life in New York City. The bulk of the collection dates from the 1900s to the mid-1920s, but scattered images can be found as early as the 1860s and as late as the 1930s. (Library of Congress) 
*********************************************************************

Very well spotted swang. His Royal Highness is wearing the same checked cap in both photographs, and you will also note Count Zeppelin appears in both photographs wearing a white peaked cap. The Royal Aero Club of the United Kingdom published a journal called Flight. (They may still do so.) In the April 5, 1913 issue of Flight on page 394 there appears this tidbit: "The Prince of Wales in Germany. During the visit of the Prince of Wales to Stuttgart last Saturday, it was anticipated that the Zeppelin Z4 would visit the city during her duration trial, but the Royal visitor had to be disappointed.The Prince went on to Friedrichschafen on Sunday and on the following day, under the guidance of Count Zeppelin, made an inspection of the works. It had been hoped that the Prince would have been able to enjoy a trip in the Z4, but this idea had to be abandoned on account of the squally weather." [ ref. www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1913/1913 - 0388.html ] Therefore, this photograph was taken on Monday March 31, 1913 outside the Zeppelin works at Friedrichschafen. Additionally, Here is the Zeppelin Museum Friedrichschafen: www.zeppelin-museum.de/ And here is a photograph of Count Zeppelin in his favoured white cap: www.zf.com/corporate/en/company/tradition/company_history... But who is hoding the umbrella and standing in the car beside the Prince of Wales? Turns out that he was Professor Hermann Georg FIEDLER. He was Professor of German at Oxford University and accompanied the Prince on his trip to Germany in 1913. See a photograph of them together on that trip here (at plate no. 43): books.google.com.au/books?id=MCxyoqsvYmYC&pg=PR27&... "The Prince of Wales inthe Easter and summer vacations of 1913 when an Oxford freshman. Hermann Fiedler, who had been Professor of German since 1907, accompanied the Prince on both occasions." [ books.google.com.au/books?id=MCxyoqsvYmYC&pg=PR27&... ]
Great sleuthing, lifeasdaddy!!

This is likely the stage, and sometime screen actress, Helen Freeman, daughter of Benjamin N. Freeman. [1] I'm locked-out from viewing page16 of Shock Myself, as referenced above by pennylrichardsca, so I can't read the reference of her "radiant blonde hair" or see the photo. That said, photos that I have seen of Ms. Freeman appear to match this LOC photograph, including this photograph in The New York Times on December 14, 1913. And this, from American Pictorial magazine, 1924. I didn't locate any authoritative, proper biographies of Helen Freeman, but there is a significant body of letters, theatrical performances, stories and books that bring-to-life her love of art, and literature, with extensive references to the frequent trips she took abroad with her lifelong friends. Collections of letters illuminating Helen Freeman are in proper collections around the world, including the Smithsonian Archives of American Art. The New York Times published an interesting theatrical biographical review of her on July 20, 1919. Helen Freeman secretly married the American writer, Edwin Corle (1906-1956), in Ensenada, Mexico in 1932. She didn't reveal her marriage until more than a year later, in December, 1933. References to her marriage are scant. Her lifetime friend, Helen Keller, closed a 3-page letter dated November 16, 1933, with: "With every good wish to the husband whom I have not had the pleasure of meeting, but whose name smiles out of your letter." — Helen Keller Her long-time friend Beatrice Wood recalled, "Helen married the (younger) writer Edwin Corle and became his "muse" for many years until he left her for a younger woman." ["Beatrice Wood: ...", Dissertation of Helen Dixon Hennessey, pp 91]   Exactly when Edwin Corle left Helen is not clear, however Aldous Huxley wrote a letter of introduction for them to T.S. Eliot in 1938:
To T. S. Eliot July 12, 1938 My dear Tom: I have given two friends of ours a letter of introduction to you. They are Edwin Corle, who is a promising young novelist, and his wife, Helen Freeman, the actress. I think you will find them a very pleasant and intelligent couple ... Ever yours affectionately, Aldous H.
I've not found any biographies of Edwin Corle that mention his marriage to Helen Freeman. The biographies do mention, however, Corle's marriage to Jean Armstrong in 1944 – so perhaps their marriage lasted close to ten years.

This image comes from the George Grantham Bain Collection which represents one of America's earliest news picture agencies. The collection richly documents sports events, theater, celebrities, crime, strikes, disasters, political activities including the woman suffrage campaign, conventions and public celebrations. The photographs Bain produced and gathered for distribution through his news service were worldwide in their coverage, but there was a special emphasis on life in New York City. The bulk of the collection dates from the 1900s to the mid-1920s, but scattered images can be found as early as the 1860s and as late as the 1930s. (Library of Congress)....

possibly Geoffrey O'Hara (February 2, 1882 - January 31, 1967), a Canadian American composer, singer and music professor
O'Hara was born in Chatham, Ontario, Canada. He initially planned a military career. O'Hara entered the prestigious Royal Military College of Canada in Kingston, Ontario at age 18 and he trained with the 1st Hussars. He had to abandon his military career upon the death of his father, Robert O'Hara. He moved to the USA in 1904, the same year he began performing in Vaudeville. He began recording for Edison Records in 1905. In 1913 O'Hara undertook the recording of traditional Indian songs on behalf of the American government. During World War I he was a singing instructor of patriotic songs for American troops. In 1919 he married Constance Dougherty from Massachusetts, and together they had two children; the same year, he became a naturalized citizen of the United States. O'Hara lectured on music and songwriting, and held positions at Teachers' College of Columbia University (1936-37), Huron College and the University of South Dakota, where he later received and honorary Doctor of Music degree in 1947. He lectured for the remainder of his life. In 1920 O'Hara helped organize The Composers' and Lyric Writers' Protective League. He also was a board member of the American Society of Composers, Authors, and Publishers (ASCAP), was the president of the Composers-Authors Guild, and served in the United Service Organizations (USO). O'Hara composed over 500 popular and patriotic songs, and hymns. He had some moderate popular music hits in the 1910s with songs such as Your Eyes Have Told Me What I Did Not Know (1913) and Tennessee, I Hear You Calling Me (1914) and one huge hit with his song K-K-K-Katy (1918), one of the most popular tunes of the World War I era." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geoffrey_O'Hara

Frances B. Roeder was an American soprano. She was the subject a few items published in the New York Times during the 1910s. She was the daughter of Augustus "Gus" Roeder of Brooklyn, a staff member of The New York World. An item published in The Times on May 18, 1913, mentioned that she was scheduled to make her debut at Covent Garden, London, as Musetta, in a production of La Boheme featuring Nellie Melba and John McCormack in the leads. But an article in the December 28, 1913 Times, when she was scheduled to sing at Nice, France, said that she had only appeared in "small parts" at Covent Garden the previous spring. Her career doesn't seem to have gone anywhere after that. By 1917, she was listed among the members of the large cast of a musical review called Cheer Up, at the Hippodrome Theatre in New York. In 1919 she married a Mr. George Chorpenning of New York, among the wedding announcements in the June 26 New York Times. After that, I find nothing about her in the archives.

He served in the United States Department of State as Counselor (1915–1919), Acting Secretary of State (1920), and Under Secretary of State (1919–1920). Polk headed the American Commission to Negotiate Peace (1919) and managed the 1924 Democratic presidential convention campaign of John W. Davis, another name partner of the firm." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frank_Polk

A collection of his papers can be found at the University of Tennessee Special Collections Library in Knoxville.

Francisco Bertrand (1866–1926) was twice President of Honduras, first from March 28, 1911 to February 1, 1912, and then again between March 21, 1913 and September 9, 1919. His successor and predecessor was Manuel Bonilla. Bertrand started out with a reputation as a conciliator, but during his last presidency was involved in armed conflict with his political opponents. It is believed that United States of America pressure was behind his abandoning the post of President. He spent the next few years in exile before returning to La Ceiba, Honduras to die in July 1926. Source: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Francisco_Bertrand

swanq, thank you for this information! We will clarify the names in the source data and reload the description.

Actually, King George I of the Hellenes (the man with the long mustache next to the Bulgarian tsar) was assassinated on March 5, 1913 as he was proceeding from the Hadjilazarou Mansion, near Thessaloniki's White Tower, to the quay to board a German naval motorboat in order to pay a protocol visit to the admiral-in-command abroad the SMS Goeben, the German imperial navy's battle-cruiser of WW1 fame. The King was conversing with his aide-de-camp, Major Fragoudis, as he was proceeding down the street when Alexandros Schinas stepped forth and shot the King once in the back. Schinas attempted to shoot Fragoudis as well but the major swiftly disarmed the assassin and surrendered him to two Cretan gendarmes, who had rushed to the scene. The King was pronounced DOA at a nearby infirmary.
Here's an official photo of King George

The above picture of the Greek King with the Bulgarian Czar (who had his two sons on his left) was shot in December 1912 after the Bulgarians lost the race to occupy Thessaloniki before an advancing Greek army arrived to liberate the city on November 5, 1912. See below a photo of King George entering Thessaloniki on horseback on that day (king on left; Prince Constantine, heir to the throne, rides alongside).

NYT article from April 21, 1921, JACK CUDAHY KILLS HIMSELF BY SHOT FROM HUNTING GUN query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9505EEDC1739E133A... summarizes Jack Cudahy's marital affairs. In 1899, he was married to Edna Corwin. In 1910, Cudahy came home to find a banker "in company with" his wife. He attacked the man and Mrs. Cudahy called the police. Shortly after they separated and then divorced. In 1912 they reconciled and remarried. They were still together when he committed suicide. So this will presumably be the former Edna Corwin. The story is definitely material for a soap opera!! And the hat is spectacular.

Mary Bartelme (1866-1954) was the first woman judge of the Circuit Court of Cook County (Chicago), assigned to the Juvenile Court (1923-1933). She was born in Chicago and earned her law degree at Northwestern; co-founder of the Chicago Business Woman's Club, active in the suffrage movement and in reforms of the juvenile justice system. Her papers are at the University of Illinois at Chicago. www.uic.edu/depts/lib/specialcoll/services/rjd/findingaid...

Dreamwold Irish Boy, best in show at the annual exhibition of the Bulldog Club of America, 1913. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9D00E2DF173DE633A...

It appears that they're on board a ferry? A. Larson is Arnold Lawson. His wife's maiden name was Lucie Mitchell. Arnold was the eldest son of Thomas W. Lawson. (NY Times, December 17, 1905) It's tough to make out the month on the left, but it appears to say 3/21/20. According to an October 3, 1922 NYTimes article, their fortunes were soon in peril. At that point Arnold's father Thomas W. Lawson was forced to sell his estate Dreamwold on the coast of Scituate, Massachusetts at a huge loss. Included in the estate was a "prized lot of police dogs". The article mentions, "After [the death of Mrs. Lawson], and with the marriage of all of their children, [Thomas W.] Lawson found the great place lonely." He'd tried many hobbies such as bulldog breeding and given up on them, finally settling on trading in the stock market and breeding police dogs. I'm not clear on what exactly caused his economic hardships, but it has to do with a "Haskell failure". So enough about the people! Let's hear about the dogs! Dreamwold Irish Boy is the bulldog. Is Noswal Neto a Pekingese? Presumably D. Irish Boy was long retired at this point. NYTimes has Dreamwold Irish Boy winning several awards: Feb 20, 1913. Westminster. Dreamwold Irish Boy wins "Bulldogs. Open. Dogs (45 pounds and over)". Mentions that Thomas W. Lawson had just spent $17,000 to bring four dogs from England with hopes of cleaning up the show, but it didn't work. D. Irish Boy wasn't one of them. Nov 5, 1913 - Thomas W. Lawson's Dreamwold Irish Boy wins Bulldog Club of America. Shown by "The Young Mr. Lawson", presumably Arnold. Feb 25, 1914 - Dreamwold Irish Boy took second place at Westminster; a different Dreamworld took second place the year before. May 10, 1914 - Irish boy took second in bulldog show, owner listed as Thomas W. Lawson. Lawson's Dreamwold Merry Boy had recently won the Bulldog Club of America. May 24, 1914 - "Irish Boy Best in Show"; lists owner as Arnold Lawson; Nassau Kennel Club annual dog show, among 600 entries; also won best Bulldog, beating English prize dog. Oddly, the same article later on says that Lawson's dog Dreamwold Centaur won a special prize available to members only. Also, in 2002 the Scituate Historical Society published a book about Dreamwold: Beauty, Strength, Speed: Celebrating 100 Years of Thomas W. Lawson's Dreamwold

Lucie Mitchell was formerly married to Herbert Barnum Seeley. according to NYT article from December 17, 1905: ARNOLD LAWSON ENGAGED.; Eldest Son of Thomas W. to Marry the Former Mrs. Herbert Seeley. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9505E5DB153AE733A... The article notes that her former husband was last heard of as a ticket-seller at the Hippodrome!!

Lucie Mitchell was formerly married to Herbert Barnum Seeley. according to NYT article from December 17, 1905: ARNOLD LAWSON ENGAGED.; Eldest Son of Thomas W. to Marry the Former Mrs. Herbert Seeley. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9505E 5DB153AE733A... The article notes that her former husband was last heard of as a ticket-seller at the Hippodrome!!
Yes, it's the same Herbert Seeley indeed - as the NY Times article in your link says, "Herbert Barnum Seeley, brother of Clinton B. Seeley, of the 'Seeley dinner' fame." The famed Seeley dinner was an 1896 private restaurant dinner busted by the police because of the nearly nude women dancers, especially the one called "Little Egypt". Herbert Seeley was the dinner's host. He married Lucie in 1900, who seems to have divorced him 1903; a first article, that they were at court, gives his worth at $400,000; the article announcing the divorce says he spent his 1900 inheritance within a few years. That, from the previous incident, isn't hard to imagine. (I read about it, BTW, in Kenneth Whyte's The Uncrowned King: The Sensational Rise of William Randolph Heart, which is on my list of the best books that crossed my desk last year.) (And yes, Boston Ave. still is - in Toronto's east end, which would have been relatively undeveloped or recently developed at the time.)

Last pieces for now! Though I'm intrigued by the dogs being important enough to name. Lucie was only 17 when she married Seeley, and 20 at that divorce. She was out of the picture by the time her father-in-law Thomas's fortune collapsed. Her husband sued her for divorce in 1920, naming one Leonard Lawrence as co-respondent; she claimed desertion. They had four children at the time. He's had detectives on her trail for months.

Her father was Melville Ezra Ingalls, a Massachusetts legislator who then became president of the Cleveland, Cincinnati, Chicago and St. Louis Railroad (the Big Four Railroad) as well as the Chesapeake and Ohio Railroad, See www.nationmaster.com/encyclopedia/Melville-E.-Ingalls and www.indianahistory.org/library/manuscripts/collection_gui...

Gladys Ingalls married Malcolm Arnold Robertson, a British diplomat, in 1917.   They met when he was first secretary in the British Embassy in Washington, and left for Europe in 1918.   Subsequently he was knighted, became Ambassador to Argentina, then an MP and chairman of a public company, and head of the British Council during the second world war.   He died in 1951.   Gladys remained in London, wanting to live near her one surviving son and his family, until her death in 1977.

There are a lot of web pages mentioning Constant Le Marin, but most are in French or German. Somebody who reads either (or both) could come up with more information about him than I can. What I've been able to glean from various sites is that he was a Belgian professional Greco-Roman wrestler, and his birth name was Henri Herd. He appears to have been popular in Russia before WWI, and might have fought on a Russian wrestling team. He had at least one bout with Stanislaus Zbyszko, at Chicago, on February 24, 1913. I also found a reference to a Belgian wrestler named Sailor Constant (an English translation of Constant Le Marin) wrestling former heavyweight boxing champion Jack Johnson in 1933. The same guy, perhaps? Both he and Johnson would have been getting on in years by then. He's also listed at BoxRec as having had a single boxing match (which he lost), against Angel Rodriguez, at Montevideo in 1916. One of the French web pages is a brief biography of his niece, Cécile Brusson, which has a couple of photos of him, one in his WWI uniform. Here's Google's automatic translation of a paragraph from it: "One of the Herd son, Henri, was an impressive athlete who, since 1904, won tournaments in Greco-Roman. He chose to fight under the name of the Constant-Marino, a tribute to the prestigious champion Namurois Constant-le-Boucher. Why marine? Because he had the ambition to "beyond the seas and oceans" the name of the school liégeoise control. He did, in fact, winning from 1908 to 1914, prestigious tournaments in Canada and South America, and it was four times world champion won his discipline and four belts of gold."

Hilltop Park at 168th Street and Broadway in upper Manhattan, was the home of the New York American League franchise now known as the Yankees (then called the Highlanders) for its first decade of existence (1903-1912). The Yankees moved across Manhattan to share the Polo Grounds with the NL's Giants (who had briefly used Hilltop Park as a home in 1911 when an earlier version of the Polo Grounds caught on fire). They were the Giants' tenants for another decade until moving across the Harlem River to the Bronx in 1923. Hilltop Park is now the site of Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center.
