A January 27, 1918 New York Times article refers to Yussif Hussane as "a Balkan" heavyweight wrestler. He was fighting Joe Stecher. I found a reference to an earlier fight between Hussane and Stecher on November 25, 1915, at Lincoln, Nebraska (on this web page). Another bout pairing the long-time rivals took place in Atlanta in 1923. He also fought Stanislaus Zbyszko at least once, in July, 1924, at the Los Angeles Philharmonic Auditorium, of all places. Other records on the Internet refer to Hussane as Bulgarian or Turkish, and he is sometimes referred to by the nickname "The Terrible Turk." I can't find any references to him fighting anywhere other than the U.S., though. He was managed for a while by American sport promoter Jack Curley, according to Curley's Wikipedia biography.

It was another, earlier Ottoman or Balkan wrestler,  Youssuf Ishmaelo, the Terrible Turk: the original (1) , in fact, of all the "Terrible Turks" who invaded western wrestling arenas over the past century,  this original via France.
Ismael Yousouf, known as the 'Terrible Turk'' to the wrestlers all over the world, was a steerage passenger on board La Bourgogne which sank in 1898. He was heading to Turkey/Ottoman Empire on the French transatlantic boat called La Bourgogne on May 21, 1898. But he couldn't end up in Istanbul and got drowned around the Sable Island (60 miles northeast to NY) due to a clash with an Irish cargo liner on July 4, 1898. His body was lost in the Atlantic Ocean.

He was born in Shumia, Turkey [now part of Bulgaria], thirty-five years ago. He was six feet two inches in height and weighted 240 pounds.Shortly after his victory over Lewis, Ismail took the first ship back to Europe where he reportedly planned to open a coffee or bazar in his native village of Scutari [in present day Albania].

The Saami people depends on travelling with their reindeer for sustenance (and many of them still do). The animals live in the north, so the people live in the north.

The "tent" is called a lavvo. Just because it looks a bit like a yurt or a teepee, this is of course not evidence of any relation. I think this is a quite natural structure to erect for shelter if you are travelling, and have access to sticks and hides. This sort of portable structure could just as well be invented independetly by different nomadic cultures.

This was the common roofs  in Norway from stoneage up the 1800s. The waterproof part is three layers of birch bark. And to prevent it from flying away, they cut slices of turf and laid over the bark.  The grass was not usually mowed, and goats were not welcome on the roof as they could make holes in the bark with their cloves.  Such a turf roof lasted for about 30 years, then all the turf and soil had to be shuffled down and new birch bark must be put in place. This was done as "dugnad", a Norwegian expression which means that all the men living around, came together and  did this work without any payment. 
Turf roofs today, used as a decorative element, have solid corrugated plastic plates instead of birch bark.
Wow, I had no idea of the origin of today's Green Roofs.  Interesting!

Not really Bandak's Canal, but the Bandak Canal i.e. the Canal leading from the ocean up to lake Bandak. Bandak is not a person, but a lake. See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bandak. The picture looks like it may have been taken directly above the Vrangfoss locks if I am not mistaken.

Yes, I agree that it resembles Trangen (position UTM32V  6573922N 51137E)
in the canalized river from Nomevatn above Vrangefoss. However,
there is not such a pathway with an uphill there. Today there is an owergrown path where I suppose there was a short railway from the quarry to the gate construction works downfalls. So short time afterwards also this bank would have been less overgrown. And there is also a small cliff in the river at Trangen, but it is not connected with the gates with this screen wall from upstream, what is the case here. And this screen comes from Vrangfoss. So this is 
the downstram inlet to Vrangfoss gatelocks (Vrangfoss' underkanal med skjermen) at position UTM 32V 6573542N 512167 E. The pathway is also today used by many canal tourists for a short walk between Eidsfoss and Vrangfoss while the canal boat is being sluiced through. The pathway was later reconstructed and diverted from the original route from the top of the uphill on towards Vrangfoss in the late 1950ies and early 60'ies when hydroelectric stations were constructed in both waterfalls. The old tourist pathway turned right from the top of the hill and crossed Yttingen or Eiebekken brook on a wooden bridge (Børtebrua) that fell down in the 1970'ies but was later reconstructed. The local shop (Børtebua) at Vrangfoss was also situated on the other side of this brook, but must have been out of business since the late 1940'ies. On the other side of the pathway from the shop, close to the river was Kongens utsikt, from where the next picture 
 in this series (with a view of the Vrangfoss locks) is taken.
I'm really liking the colorized look with all of these library of congress shots, good stuff

Eidsfoss all right, at the Bandakkanal (Norsjø-Bandakkanalen) - the locks and waterfall between Ulefoss (3 km downstream) and Vrangfoss (0,8 km upstream). Would estimate picture to be shot from Eiestranda (UTM32V 144360 N, 47746 E), not as far downstream on the right (western) bank as Striken (UTM32V 143983 N, 47826 E). The central part of the picture is Eidsfoss locks (UTM32V 144614 N, 47643 E) with the old "needle dam" (torn down in the early 1960'ies and replaced with a modern dam when the third and present hydropower station was built in the waterfall, the first constructed during WWI) The nearest buildings in the hillside were built for the workers manning the canal gates in traffic (in Norwegian: slusevokterboligen) Higher in the hillside (Hølalia i Stangefjell) is the quarry (for granite blocks for the construction of the canal) freshly visible in the forest. The old road between Ulefoss and Lunde (Skaravegen) passes between "slusevokterboligen" www.flickr.com/photos/nilsenhelgeir/4056481130/ and the quarry. Further north on this road, over the highest part of the locks is the cottage Eidshaug visible in the forest (at UTM32V145029N 47536E) (Eidshaug, sjå: www.flickr.com/photos/nilsenhelgeir/4055737355/ eller: www.flickr.com/photos/nilsenhelgeir/4055736519/ . The forests were owned by the Aall family at Ulefos manor and the cottage was rented to their loggers / crofters. The view is mainly unchanged since then with the exception of the most recent hydropower plant and dam at the waterfall.

The travelling photographer obviously was onboard a boat going from Skien up the Telemark Canal ending here in Dalen. From here, they went over the mountain to Hardangerfjorden, and crossed from Voss to Sognefjorden. This was apparently a popular trip among the wealthy at that time. It's mentioned in a book about the history of this hotel. Of course, it is still possible and recommendable to do today.

This waterfall was 'tamed' in 1905 to provide hydro-electricity for the company that would later become Norsk Hydro. In fact, it provided electricity for Hydro's Rjukan plant, famed for the WW2 sabotage attack by 'the Heroes of Telemark'. It's rarely seen in such a state nowadays - it's normally more of a trickle (although not in this photo). A shame to harness such a natural wonder maybe, but Norway's not short of spectacular waterfalls, and this one helped to put Norway on the path to being an industrialized nation.

Thank you for an amazing photo !  As a Kongsberg native I would like to inform that the city is part of Buskerud county ( fylke ) and not Telemark. Telemark is the nabouring fylke : )
Thank you for this information! We will correct the source data and reload the description.

hskinnes: Sure, Kongsberg is part of what's today known as Buskerud fylke, but when this picture was taken, there were no such thing as neither Buskerud, nor Telemark fylke. Those are political/administrative units created in 1919. Back then, most of what is today known as Telemark fylke, was Brattsberg amt, and Buskerud was first Ringerike, Hallingdal, Eiker og Buskeruds amt, and later just Buskerud amt. The name Telemark was used as for a geographical, not political, area. And Kongsberg is no doubt part of Telemark in that sense, just as Grenland is not. Since Telemark was chosen as the name of the county in 1919, the meaning of Telemark has since shifted towards including Grenland, and excluding Kongsberg. We still have Kongsberg regionsråd which includes municipalities in both counties.

Picture from the upper part of Longyeardalen / Longyear Valley
The Snebrae=glacier  is named Longyearbreen (Longyear glacier).
Left side is the mountain Sarkofagen (also called Kistefjellet, sarkofag=kiste)
Right side of glacier is Nordenskiöldfjellet (1050m)

In spite of the caption, this suspiciously looks like Sarkofagen (in Longyeardalen), with its unmistakeable shape, doesn't it? And answering to myself: this is most probably Longyeardalen, taken at the height of the small tributary valley from west called Tverrdalen - and that is Sarkofagen.

csant; You are definitely right, this is Longyeardalen and Sarkofagen.
The photo is shot a few hundred meters up from the seashore.
The valley witch today is called Tverrdalen takes off to the west at the end moraines of the Longyearbreen. This glacier is located to the right of the mountain Sarkofagen.

To the caption; This valley is located at Advent Bay / Adventfjorden, and the valley of Longyeardalen got its name in 1905 or 06, after the place Longyear City was established the year after JM Longyear took over / bought the rights to take out coal from the area. 
After some research, maps or papers prior to 1905 does not state any name of the valley - So - for the moment the name Tverdalen seems to be a plausible truth!
Name translation Tverdalen; "side valley" or geological "valley that runs counter to the direction of the geological layers"

100 years later Tourists still visit Spitsbergen. A little further west along the Adventfjord, but partly the same mountain-view as seen in the postcard of the tourist's house here above.
This must be photographed after 1905, since the "sildesalat" (herring salad) is not present in the Norwegian flag. See: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Union_badge_of_Norway_and_Sweden
epikuros1: Sildesalaten was discontinued in 1898. It says so in your source. May I suggest you read it better the next time?

Of course, always do! The norwegian state flag got rid of the herring salad in practice on the 15th december 1899 (not in 1898). But this is not a state flag, it is a split flag (orlogsflagg). Split flags continued to have the herring salad until a couple of days after the dissolution of the union. But when I look at this flag more closely I have to say it looks more like a "postal flag" - I therefore hope a norwegian postal historian could enlighten us more on this issue.

Surely this must be what is mentioned here: "In 1896 Vesteraalens Steamship Co built a simple tourist hotel in Advent Bay and started a regular service between the mainland and Svalbard." Source: home.online.no/~polar-ps/engtxt1.html

The flag above is most likely to be a Norwegian postal flag. 
As in geirrosset source - Fred G writes; the Norwegian postal authorities puts up a "letter house" in this tourist house.  
Mind you; Spitsbergen is at this time still a No Mans Land!
This official action by the postal authorities creates attention in the media, and opens again up the debate about Spitsbergen's international status and the wish to get the archipelagos under Norwegian sovereignty.

This is the sea-side view of the tourist house situated at  Adventpyten close to the entrance of Advent Bay. Later on the area is called Hotellneset.
The tourist house was in 1908 moved to Longyear City or Skjæringa, some 4 km east.

The date of this picture is likely July 11, 1897, or shortly before. "Andree" is Salomon August Andrée, who attempted to reach the North Pole with a hydrogen balloon. The expedition was a complete failure and led to the deaths of Andrée and his two companions, Knut Frænkel and Nils Strindberg. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/trialsanderrors/2750590073]
Thanks for supplying a more precise date. We'll fix the source data and reload the description.

Arnold Pike, an Englishman, put up the house to the right of Andrées balloon house in 1888. Andrée used this house during both attempts, 1896 and 1897, to reach the North Pole with his balloon Örnen.
Andrée renamed in 1896 this small bay on the northern side of Danskøya to "Virgos hamn" after his transport vessel S/S "Virgo". Today's name is Virgohamna.
Fridtjof Nansen visited the bay in 1912 and he describes the constructions bear evidence of heavy decay.

The battle for the North Pole Virgohamna on Danskøya of today. Andrée's balloon house stood at the foot of the hill - see note. (The note does not follow the image. You have to visit me to check it up!) The remains in the foreground is from the Walter Wellman expeditions in 1906, 1907 and 1909. He tried to reach the North Pole with the airship America. This image is shot 1992 on reversal film.

The newer photo is taken from the head of the fjord at the cite of Gudvangen. The old one is from farther north, and in the foreground we have the path built for the postman around 1650. The post route between Oslo (then Christiania) and Bergen usually used a rowboat here, but when bad ice covered the fjord, the postman used the path we can see a part of here in the front. The path ended at the farm Styvi which you just can see in the background as a white dot close to the sea. Farther north, there usually was no ice on the fjord.

The name today is written Kjelfossen. 
It is 840 meters high, and the official statistic of Norway (Statistic yearbook 2008) lists this waterfall as the highest in Norway.   
Kjelfossen is easily seen from E16, the main road between Oslo and Bergen.

Supphellebreen in Sogn & Fjordane is the lowest-lying glacier of Norway.

This glacier is now divided in two where the low part at the bottom of the valley is doomed to melt and disappear unless a major shift in glacial accumulation and transport from the top of the glacier is re-established.

While physical approach to the glacier itself is possible it is stricly recommended to keep proper distance as the glacier is constantly yielding ice rockets.

The Supphellebre is still there, but is not quite so big today. You can drive by car close to it. If you have time, you might sit down and wait for a while, and if you are lucky, you will see a huge avalanche fall from the glacier at the top, down to the lower one with a lot of noise. This will happen during the day, but no one knows when. An English film photographer waited a whole day, but no avalanche occured. He had just packed all his gear in the car and was ready to drive away, then the avalanche came.

That would be Bodø, Norway

Nordlandskatedralen is not "still standing", Bodø Domkirke however is built at its spot.

Almost all of Bdø was bombed by the germans at may 27th 1940, leaving only a few bulidings standing.

This is taken by one of Bodø's first professional photographers. Her name was Louise Engen (1873-1947), and she grew up on a farm called Jensvoll - just a few kilometers outside today's city center. 

She got her photography education in Oslo, England and USA before returning to Bodø.

The local museum here in Bodø has got a copy of this photo as well, and states that it's taken somewhere between 1900 and 1940.

I think this photo was taken from the island "Store Hjertøya" late July, between 6 and 8 PM, based on the angle of the light.
Wow, what a neat photo, and great find. My mother's family was from this town, but immigrated to the US before WW2.

Reminds me of a Viking long ship
correct spelling is Nordlandsbåt -- Seen in your Photochrom Travel Views set. (?)
And, for clarification, "Nordlandsbåt" is the name of this kind of ship, not a geographical location.
It's outside Svolvær in Lofoten

Greeboe, you are very right. The "nordlandsbåt" is considered to be a direct descendant of the Viking long ships. It comes in many sizes and regional variants, but they all look very similar. I believe the type shown on this picture was used in the annual Lofoten cod-fishing campaign, way into the 20th century. A few local boat-builders still do variants of the "nordlandsbåt" today.

Classification of the big boat is "Fembøring" (size). This classification is the bigest of the "Nordlands boat hulls" and was almost used as freight boat belong the coasline in North Norway. The design of hull tell me it`s built in Saltdal.

The small boat classification is "Kjeks". In some disticts of N-N "tororing". The number of room in the boat tell the class of boat. The boat is very fast in the water to row and was also a fast sail boat. The most usual sail was square sail. But it was important with experience for to prevent to capsize. They used enough with ballast with globular stones correct located in the boat. If the boat capsized the globular stones fell out of the boat and it was easy to bring it on keel again.

Ottimamente risulta la nitidezza nonché appropriata pertanto non troppo marcata ma nemmeno scialba e impastata. Contestualmente la luce non diretta crea una sorta di diffurione generale che crea nelle aree in ombra un timbro uniforme molto gradevole. Inoltre la sua gestione conferisce un’ottima rappresentazione generale degli elementi e sopratutto del soggetto che si ambienta molto bene nel contesto. Nota un appropriato e fievole viraggio molto probabbilmente causato dalla caduta di luce ma tutto ciò ha dato un’impronta caratteriale al fotogramma e ha evidenziato maggiormente il timbro cromatico della pelle del soggetto. Complimenti per l’ottima immagine restituita nella quale il corretto bilanciamento cromatico accompagnato da una gradevolissima nitidezza e l’ottima risoluzione ha restituito una immagine veramente piacevole. Ben curato il bilanciamento del bianco, nonostante la caduta di luce, e la restituzione dei toni nell’insieme dell’immagine. Digermulen again, still 1896.
We still see the old sailboat, jekt, in the harbour.
In the foreground drying grass.
We see the big house where fish was processed, there were a pub there, rooms for fishermen, salt, barrels and so on.
The small white house was the general store.
Then the big house of the owner, at this time it was Normann.
The smaller house for the workers, and behind it the bakery.
Then in front the red barn.
At the shore there are two fishermans huts, rorbuer.
I just wonder if Kaiser Wilhelms fotographer, Dreesen, are the man behind those pictures.

This picture is probably from 1896 or so.
At this time mass-tourism had started.
Digermulen is considered the birt-place of tourism in Northern-Norway.

This is not a barn.
It is a boathouse and a fishermans hut in Lauksund on the island of Brakøya, Raftsund, Lofoten.
Wonderful and surreal colours.

Trollfjord, the fjord of fjords.
Almost 3 kilometer long, but only 100 meter wide at the entrance.
Originally called Svartfjorden, Black Fjord, in Germany known as Teufelskanal, the Devils Channel.
Entrance to Trollfjord – Then and Now (100+ years later)   "Sailing in Trollfjord (2002)" by WeeHaggis    "Troldfjord (c.1900)"       by Detroit Publ.
Great comparison

We see the inner harbour of the fishing village of Svolvær. The bay on the left is called Pollen. Lofoten was and still is dependent on the large amount of cod in this area. The boat houses are called "rorbuer", and can house seasonal fishermen and their boats when they come in winter from elsewhere in Norway to participate in the fisheries.

A good view of current Svolvær, but from the opposite angle, can be found here: 
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/stighs/2739673516/]

"Nordkap", in modern Norwegian "Nordkapp", known in English as "North Cape". One tells tourists this is Europe's northernmost point, but that's not really true- it's the furthest north you can drive a car, though...

"Opstigning" means something like "Ascending" - best translated as "The way up to North Cape" - assuming they got there by boat and had to walk/climb all the way up.

It's Sivlefossen, actually, not Silve-, like the Norwegian poet Per Sivle (1857-1904) - raised at the farm just above this waterfall.

A little more about the scenery. Per Sivle was not born here but at Flaam where his mother came from, but his father was from this place and Sivle also grew up here living with relatives as his mother died early in his age. We are not in the area of Hardangerfjord, This place is a short drive from Gudvangen at Naeroyfjord, a branch of Sognefjorden.

This valley ("-dalen") is by the Sognefjord, not Hardangerfjord. The view is Nærøydalen (old spelling: Nærødalen) looking from the county of Hordaland into the county of Sogn & Fjordane. Together with famous Nærøyfjord, an arm of Sognefjord, the area today is protected by UNESCO’s World Heritage List.
The current hotel is the fourth hotel to be built at Stalheim. the first was built 1885 and the three hotels preceeding the current one were all destroyed by fire.

Stalheim Hotel – Then and Now (100+ years later) As christenm.heiberg commented, these are views of the 1st and 4th hotels on this site. The first hotel, built in 1885, initially had ten guest rooms, however wings and refurbishments rapidly extended the size of the original hotel. It was destroyed by fire in 1900. Immediately rebuilt, the second hotel burnt down in 1902. In 1906, Meinhardt's Hotel in Voss was bought, dismantled and moved to Stalheim. Sadly, it was lost to fire in 1959, along with loss of life. The current hotel, built in 1960, has 124 guest rooms. [1] [2] [3] "Stalheim Hotel (2008)" by Don Murphy1 "Stalheim Hotel (c. 1900)" by Detroit Pub.

This is the Tvinde Hotel, located in Voss Parish. It was advertised as a 'new hotel with all modern conveniences', around the time this photograph was taken (1895). It had 15 rooms (with 25 beds), and boasted "Fishing from the banks of the river" as well as "Horses and Carriages Kept" and "English Spoken". The proprietor was David Tvinde. (Tvinde is apparently also a place name.) The resident hosts in 1910 were Johan W. Furubo, his wife Hildur, and their eight year-old daughter, Alma Marie. [1] [2] [3] [4] With the hotel as close to the falls as it was, I imagine the sound would either put one to sleep immediately -- or keep one up most of the night.
View in 2008: www.panoramio.com/photo/47285598

Vossebanen (Bergen-Voss) Open in 1883.

Who would believe that this town is actually the origin of Voss water :P ?

Actually, the Voss water doesn't come from Voss - it comes from an even smaller place called Vatnestraum, not far from Kristiansand in the south of Norway. Until recently, the inhabitants of Vatnestraum had exactly the same water to use in their showers and toilets.

I guess they chose the name "Voss" because "Vatnestraum" might not be a perfect international brand name.
Voss is not along the Hardanger fjord. It is situated on the shore of the lake called Vangsvatnet.

This is a very special picture from Vøringsfossen waterfall! The most visited waterfalls in Norway in many ways. You drive the famous Måbøvalley and you can visit the waterfall in 30 minutes walk. I would strongly recommend to bring with you a guide to get the dramatic history about the hard way of living here ,the avalanches, roadbuilding and about the Fossli Hotel. Edvard Grieg was here too composing! The surroundings are like Grand Canyon! Waterfall is 182 meeters high! And the bridge is brand new in 2008!
The waterfall is still as beautiful as ever! and you can see the rainbow crossing the waterfall between 5 and 7pm
If you ever come to NOrway, visit it! Welcome to Eidfjord!
You will never forget the place!

Hammerfest was struck by fire in 1890, which wiped out almost half its buildings. In 1891 Hammerfest was the first town in Northern Europe to have electrical street lights. The town was fortified by the germans during WW2, and was completely wiped out leaving only a church standing when the germans fled the allies february 14th 1945. Hammerfest nowadays is a modern town with a population of app 10 000. Shipping port for LNG both to the US and Europe. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hammerfest
In the Hammerfest area there have been found arciological artifacts that proves that the area have been populated for about 11 000 years.
This is aproximatly the same view of the modern Hammerfest. Not as charming as we lost all of the old wooden architecture at the end of World War 2.

As mentioned above, the settlement in Hammerfest goes way back in time, and as  a matter of fact, in the front of the picture you can see some depressions in the  field, whis are remains of houses dating back to the younger stone age, aprox. 5000 years old.

Very cool to see what it look like 100 years ago. Taken in 2006:
Wow... fantastic shots !
What strikes me is the lack of trees a hundred years ago, probably due to today's reduced grazing from goats and sheep.

Speaking of goates and sheeps. you are right. The vegitation IS keapt donwn due to farming and animal grazing. This is why Norway has the worlds most beautiful fjords. There are fjords elsewhere too - e.g. in Alaska, but there are few places in the world where vegitation is keapt down by the farming and animal grazing. In fact no other creature would be able to live in the steep, rocky mountains surrounding the fjords i Norway.

Where people and animal live, the trees and grass is keapt down. This is what makes the Norwegian fjords uniqe in the world.

By the way: the name fjord or fiord (pronounced /fjɔːd/ or pronounced /fiːɔːd/) has its origin from the norse (ancient  norwegian language) word farda, which means to travel or to go (to the other side - accross the fjord).

The mountain Hornindalsrokken is situated at the end of a valley branching off to the north from the main valley of Hornindal in Sogn og Fjordane (county), Norway. Its peak marks the border between Sogn og Fjordane and Møre og Romsdal counties, and rises 1529 meters above sea level.

Hornindalsrokken and the Geiranger fjord are 15 km (about 10 miles) apart, so the title "Hornindalsrokken, Geiranger Fjord" is somewhat misleading. "Hornindalsrokken, Nordfjord, Norway" would be better. Nordfjord is one of the fjords of Sogn og Fjordane, and it has given name to the district in the northern part of this county. The valley (municipality) Hornindal is then part of the Nordfjord district.

Dear Library of Congress! I grew up at the foot of this mountain. Well, our farm is actually around 5km away from the mountain, but our mountain farm (sæter) is right at the bottom of this mountain. We would spend most of the summers there :-) The mountain is NOT situated at the Geirangerfjord. Maybe that piece of information was added, due to many visiting the Geirangerfjord would do roundtrips of the region, (either to Romsdal with Trollstigen in the north or) to Nordfjord in the south. The Nordfjord roundtrip includes the glaciers at Briksdal or Lodal (part of Jostedalen). They would go by cars with chauffeurs, and these trips would take a couple of days, before returning to Geiranger. Many of the tourists around the 1890 came to Geiranger on boats, the early cruise ships. The Nordfjord roundtrip passes this mountainview, the image is taken from the roadside. Hornindalsrokken is the most southern of the Sunnmørsalpane, the mountain area discovered by famous mountaineers such as Patchell, Slingsby, Randers and Mohn in the 1890ies. These mountains surround the Hjørundfjord, also a very beautiful fjord, that have had a large share of Norwegian fjord-tourism ever since. A little bit about Sunnmørsalpene can be found here, but the article is very short in English version...: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sunnm%C3%B8rsalpene More about Hornindalsrokken here: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hornindalsrokken

Christiania seems to have a long tradition of slightly odd architecture, including things built outward like this one. This was in my contacts' photos just last week: www.flickr.com/photos/dgbalancesrocks/3179720688/
A "stabbur" is a small building made for storage of food. I believe the "outward" style has something to do with keeping mice and rats out of the building.

I would guess that this "stabbur" is located in an outdoor museum located at Bygdøy in Oslo called Norsk Folkemuseum (Norwegian folk museum). Christiania is an old name of Norways capital Oslo. The museum have, among other things,  a collection of old norwegian buildings, and it was founded in 1894.


Lú: The Christiania in the picture you are linking to is in Denmark. It's a part of Copenhagen.
Oh well! Carry on :)
This is indeed at the Folkemuseum. I feel a huge urge go there immediately and get a "now" shot from this angle!
Hi, I'm an admin for a group called Barns of the World., and we'd love to have this added to the group!

Oslo was called Christiania (or Kristiania) from 1624 to 1924. It was named after the Danish King Christian which was ruler of Denmark-Norway in 1624. Nowadays, Christiana is the name of an area in Copenhagen.

*dfoster: this is not a barn, but a dedicated food storage. All big farms used to have them, and the upward and outward growing shape is indeed to make it harder for mice to climb the walls. You'll notice that there is a gap between the stairs and the "stabbur" proper for the same reason.
torw: thanks for clearing that up :) Just wanted to add that alot of Norwegian farms still have them and many are still in use. They're great for storing cured meats and potatoes :)
just to clearify, i believe the english term for stabbur is "granary". this abviously shows a norwegian one, but they exist all over the world. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Granary
This is snapped at Norsk folkemuseum in 2009.

A stabbur would have more than just grain; it would also be used to prepare and store meat, fish and other provisions.  It's raised from the ground by stones to protect the contents from vermin and moisture.

A stabbur is still in use but are often rebuilt in better shape to be used today.They still use the old style but are mostly paited red.
At the folk museum in Oslo they are brown ,perhaps since they only used tar (?)1500-1800 +/- a.c.
The barn and the stabbur used only to be painted red (after the paint where widly used after 1900 (?)) and the main house white.(I dont know why)People where very poor and I bet paint where considered a luxury.
It is prohibited for people to live in a Stabbur,only for storage.But today all kind of storage.I bet u might us it like an office,but no people can sleep there.
The timeline is a lot of guesswork,since I am not a historian.
tremendous difference in 100 years, old is gold i must say.

The Royal Palace

The Danish-born architect Hans Ditlev Franciscus Linstow (1787-1851) was commissioned to design the new palace.
The Royal Palace was built as a residence for King Carl Johan (then king of Norway and Sweden), but was not completed until spring 1849, after his death. On 15 March 1849 the Lord Chamberlain took possession of the new palace on behalf of King Oscar I, and on 26 July it was formally inaugurated in the presence of the whole Royal Family.

The proposal to build a royal residence in Oslo was raised in the Storting (Norwegian national assembly) for the first time in 1821, but this was not followed up until the following year, when King Carl Johan himself proposed it to the Storting. In spite of the pressures on the Norwegian economy, the Storting allocated 150,000 rix-dollars for the work, and in 1823 a commission was appointed to oversee the sale of government bonds to finance the project and to have overall responsibility in matters concerning the building. By 1827 the palace foundations were completed. However, the allocated money had already been spent, and between 1827 and 1833 all building work ceased, since the Storting was not willing to grant further funds. The original plan was a building in the shape of an H, but this had to be revised for financial reasons, and it was decided to build a simple U shape. When King Carl Johan died in 1844, it was immediately apparent that the Palace would be too small for the new Royal Family. The Storting therefore granted an additional allocation for the purpose of beautifying the exterior and enlarging the wings. The original roof, which no one had considered to be satisfactory, was lowered, and a monumental temple front with pillars was added to the main façade.

A variety of changes have been made to the Palace since it was first inhabited in 1849. At the end of the century the sanitation was improved and electricity was installed. Until King Haakon and Queen Maud arrived in Norway in 1905, the Palace had only been lived in for short periods at a time, during visits to Oslo by the Norwegian-Swedish King. It was therefore quite unsuitable as a permanent home for the new Royal Family. In order to meet their needs a set of Royal apartments was installed, with bathrooms and lavatories.
Minor rehabilitation and maintenance work was undertaken during King Olav’s reign (1957-1991).

The Royal Palace is owned by the state and placed at the disposal of the head of state. When Harald V became king at the beginning of the 1990s, a survey of the building showed that it was in need of a complete renovation.
The state of the electrical system aroused concern, the kitchens and sanitation had seen very little improvement since 1906 and the working conditions for the staff did not comply with the national working environment regulations. The fire alarm system and fire walls were inadequate and the emergency exits were not secure. The façade had not been properly maintained and there was discovered rot in the floor beams. The layout of the rooms was functionally impractical. 

In 1993 the Royal Court presented a general plan for the renovation of the Palace, and the Directorate of Public Construction and Property was given the task of restoring the building and upgrading the Royal Apartments. The rebuilding and rehabilitation was carried out in consultation with the Royal Family and representatives of the state, the Royal Court and the Directorate for Cultural Heritage. The work involved comprehensive and complicated changes.

On 15 March 1999, 150 years to the day after the Lord Chamberlain took possession of the original building, the Directorate of Public Construction and Property was able to deliver a completely restored and renovated building. The furnishing and decoration of the Royal Apartments was undertaken as a separate project in 1999 under the leadership of the Royal Court. The apartments were completed in spring 2001.

Facts
Laying of the foundation stone: 1 October 1825
Inauguration: 1849 
The base measures 3.593,3 m² 
Length of the main wing: 100,8 m
Width of the main wing: 24,1 m 
Length of the side wings: 40,7 m
Width of the side wings: 14,3 m
Height: 25 m
Total area: 17,624 m² 
Number of rooms: 173

The University

The University of Oslo is Norway’s largest and oldest institution of higher education. It was founded in 1811 when Norway was still under Danish rule. As a satellite of the modest Danish kingdom until early in the 19th century, Norway was understandably not among the first places to found a university. The larger kingdoms of medieval Europe – Italy, France, England – established their first universities as early as the 12th century. The Scandinavian monarchies, Sweden and Denmark at the time, opened their first universities at Uppsala in 1477 and at Copenhagen in 1479, respectively. In 1811, the Danish monarch King Frederick VI granted Norway the right to found its own university. Det Kongelige Frederiks Universitet (The Royal Frederick University) opened in Oslo in 1813. At the start, conditions were meagre; classes were held in rented buildings. The early modest period persisted for almost half a century, before the University had its own building complex. Although builders laid the cornerstone of the first building in 1841, the first lecture was not held at the new university until 1853. By 1856 construction work on three buildings was finally completed on Oslo’s main boulevard, Karl Johans gate (then Slotsveien). In 1923, university administrators and the Norwegian government agreed to develop a new campus just outside of the downtown area in a neighbourhood called Blindern. Because of an economic recession, however, the plans were shelved. Only in 1931 could the first institutes move to the new campus. In the 1960s the Greater Blindern area was developed. This area is today associated by most people as the centre of the University of Oslo. One of the four original faculties at the University of Oslo, The Faculty of Law, are still using the old buildings.

Grand Hotel

The Grand Hotel first opened its doors in 1874. The Louis XVI revival style building, with its hint of Nordic art nouveau and characteristic clock tower from 1913, is right on Karl Johans gate, Oslo's main street. The hotel has been extended and modernized over the years, and today, the Grand Hotel has 290 rooms, including 52 suites, 15 conference rooms, and a number of restaurants and bars. 
The Grand Hotel has been the talk of the town since the days of playwright Henrik Ibsen.

This summer castle was buildt 1847-52, and the architect was Johan Henrik Nebelong for King Oscar I. Oscarshall was sold by King Carl IV to the Norwegian state in 1863, and has been at the disposal of Norwegian kings since.

The building is considered one of the main neo-Gothic works in Norway. The architectural style is patterned on the English neo-Gothic castle, which was typical in Scandinavia in the mid-19th century. In addition to the main building, the property consists of a park that stretches down to the fjord, where an open pavilion is located.

The interior was wholly constructed by Norwegian artists and artisans.

The castle is now closed for restoration, but will open for the public soon.

The original at Borgund, built around 1150 AC, still stands in its original status.

My grandmother lived in this town and she was born in 1901.  She were very proud of Ålesund.  If you visit Ålesund you have to go to the spot named Fjellstua.  It may  give you a marvolus view.  There was a terrible fire in 1904 and Ålesund needed help to been built up.  Keiser Wilhelm from Germany was very keen of the town and gave us a great help.  One of the main streets is today named  the Keiser Wilhelm street.  However, as we know,  in 1940 the Germans went back,  but now as enimies.

My dad was born here and my husband and I were fortunate to have traveled there 4 years ago to stay with relatives.  The town is breathtaking and we did go up to Fjellstua (the food wasn't being served there it was early March).  Jokki---your image is completely breathtaking!! I have the same view in a pic that I made in a 30X40 canvas for me....LOVE this view!!  We have relative on Molde as well.

The Library of Congress dates this picture between 1890 and 1900. A more accurate dating would be the summer of 1897. My conclusion is based on the following: 
The City Hall which is the red brick building with its clock tower (behind the aft spar of the steamer) stood ready in December 1896 and was inaugurated on January 9, 1897. The former City Hall (built 1799) which is the two storeys high gray building to the right of the new City Hall was demolished before the end of 1897. As pedestrians and passengers on the steamer are lightly dressed and use sunshades it has to be late spring, summer or august at the latest.
This adds to the accumulating evidence that the pictures were taken during a Scandinavian trip in 1897: S.A. Andrée's 1897 Arctic expedition, 1897 Stockholm World's Fair.
Thanks!  We'll fix the date in the source data and reload the description.

I'm curious about the flag on the boat--is it Danish or Swedish? My computer displays it in an ambiguous manner.

It's likely a mix of the two, symbolizing the ferry service between Sweden and Denmark: (unless it's the "herring salad", as klipspringer commented above, but in that case the vertical blue line is missing.)

I checked Flag of Denmark in Wikipedia  and found information about the type of flag it is.  It's more likely a Danish flag.  Here's the information I copied from Wikipedia, "The Splitflag or Orlogsflag have similar specifications, but legally, they are two different flags. The Splitflag is a Danish flag ending in a swallow-tail, it is Dannebrog red, and is used on land. The Orlogsflag is a Splitflag with a deeper red colour and is only used on sea."

Great photo!!...)

But where is Copenhagen in this picture? I did a little research. Copenhagen is about 27 miles away from Helsingborg, Sweden! There is no way that this picture shows part of Copenhagen! In your description, "Photo shows a paddle steamer, possibly named Kopenhagen or København, in the Helsingborg harbor." I could not see the name on the ship. I wonder if the original title "Copenhagen" means the steamer, not the city. On the photo, the text is "Kopenhagen. Helsingborg", which also showed that  "Kopenhagen" could be the name of the steamship.
Someone reckons this was "one of the first ones [ferries] shuttling between Helsingør [Denmark] and Helsingborg [Sweden]": thethingsienjoy.blogspot.com/2012/03/helsingr-helsingborg...

Earlier in the comments, there was discussion about the color of the flag at the ship's stern. Colors on the photochroms can be deceiving, because they were applied by hand. But the colorist definitely reckoned the flagon the square tower was blue (Swedish) and the flags on the ferry were red (Danish). I was struck by the house flag flown on the tallest mast of the ferry. The maltese cross was on the house flag of the United Steamship Co., Copenhagen, according to www.crwflags.com/fotw/flags/dk~hfs.html and from en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DFDS it appears that the company ran ferries to Sweden at the time period in question. The DFDS website states that the house flag has always had a blue background [www.dfdsgroup.com/about/logo/]. But the colorist may not have known that. The same flag page has a flag with a maltese cross and red background, but the company [ib.frath.net/w/Store_Nordiske_Telegrafselskab_A/S] was a telecommunications company, whose ships would have been for laying cables. According to www.shipping-info.net/db.html DFDS had several paddle-steamers around this time running local routes including: KJØBENHAVN ( I ) support.boge.com/shipinfo.nsf/f06338a0b832260dc1256ba0004... H.P. PRIOR support.boge.com/shipinfo.nsf/f06338a0b832260dc1256ba0004... GYLFE support.boge.com/shipinfo.nsf/NameView/7F18957A6BF888F6C1... GEFION support.boge.com/shipinfo.nsf/NameView/92D654E4CCF6A9F6C1... EDDA (later KURUREN) support.boge.com/shipinfo.nsf/f06338a0b832260dc1256ba0004... CLANDEBOYE (later GJEDSER) support.boge.com/shipinfo.nsf/f06338a0b832260dc1256ba0004... DRONNINGEN support.boge.com/shipinfo.nsf/f06338a0b832260dc1256ba0004... HEBE support.boge.com/shipinfo.nsf/f06338a0b832260dc1256ba0004... KOLDINGHUUS support.boge.com/shipinfo.nsf/f06338a0b832260dc1256ba0004... AALBORG support.boge.com/shipinfo.nsf/f06338a0b832260dc1256ba0004... CHRISTIANIA support.boge.com/shipinfo.nsf/f06338a0b832260dc1256ba0004... ZAMPA support.boge.com/shipinfo.nsf/f06338a0b832260dc1256ba0004... However, the database does not list any of these as running particularly into Helsingborg. Nor does it have pictures.

A bit more exploring did unearth a couple of pictures that look very like this paddle-steamer: www.simplonpc.co.uk/Oresund.html#anchor418708 has pictures of sister ships owned by DFDS in the 1890s. "The two paddlesteamers Gylfe and Gefion were built in 1974 [sic] by Burmeister & Wain of Copenhagen for DFDS." They were sold in 1900. They ran from Copenhagen to Malmö. But since DFDS commissioned several paddle-steamers from the same builder in the mid-1870s, the one in this photo could be any of them. It is less likely to be the Kjøbenhavn, because that was built in Scotland in 1869.

A different angle, but the entrance to Tivoli was unchanged in September 1963 - and I am sure it is still the same. If you were rich, you probably came by carriage. If not, perhaps in a horse-drawn omnibus like the one at lower right of the original. Or you walked, like most of the people in the original photo.

"Die Börse" translates as the "Stock Exchange" or "Børsen". Børsen (The Stock Exchange) is a building on the island Slotsholmen in central Copenhagen built by Christian IV in 1619-1640. The building was designed by Hans van Steenwinckel in the style of the Dutch renaissance architecture and is famous among tourists for its "dragonspire". The spire from 1625 is shaped as the tails of four dragons twined together. The tower measures 56 meters. The building was restored by Nicolai Eigtved in 1745 and internally renovated in 1855. It housed the Danish stock-market until 1974. In 1918, unemployed anarchists attacked Børsen, an attack that went to the Danish history books as "stormen på Børsen" (the storm at the stock exchange). (from Wikipedia)

This is the hike led by "General" Rosalie Jones from New York to Washington, DC for the March 3, 1913 suffrage parade. Further, I believe this is in Newark, New Jersey on February 12, 1913. It would be worth looking at period photos of Newark for comparison. The Buick in the foreground has a New York license plate, number 35227 from 1913, and has “Official Scout” tarped over the engine. The vehicle on the right has plate 8515 which appears to say “NJ” in the top right and “13” below it: New Jersey Plates. The car on the left, 1226, also has a blurry “NJ” with some sort of circular mark and then “13” below it. The layout matches New Jersey’s porcelain plates from 1913, with red text and a metal seal where the circular mark is. Information about this hike is in a number of New York Times and Washington Post articles starting January, 1913. NYTimes Jan 13, 1913 p22 "18-day March to Capital" describes Jones' announcement of the hike in Philadelphia. Wa Post Feb 13 1913 p1 “Cold Feet in Ranks” describes the zero-degree walk in New Jersey on day one, where the core 16 hikers were accompanied by 184 single dayers. Wa Post Feb 18 1913 p1 “Army Escapes Rout” describes the marchers snowballed and stoned by young boys and laughed at by adults near Chester, Pennsylvania – finally they were escorted by cadets on horseback from the Chester Military College. NY Times Feb 24 1913 p11 “Col. Craft Defiant” describes stragglers' arrival in Baltimore. Wa Post Feb 24 1913 p1 “Two Armies Now” describes fourteen of the original sixteen arriving in Baltimore. Wa Post Feb 25 1913 p2 “Pilgrims Not Weary” arranging for Thursday reception at Washington, DC. Wa Post Feb 27 1913 p1 “Race Barrier is Up” describes the hikers’ plans to disband if they are joined by a group of negro women planning to hike with them into Washington – also describes cold shoulder given to marchers who attempted to join them at Laurel, Md with a flag “Votes for negro women”. Wa Post Feb 28, 1913 p1 “Army at City Gates” describes route planned into Washington, and the harsh treatment into Bladensburg, Md – after being jeered the entire way, at College Park the men with them were forced to fight off angry college students in the heavy rain. I thought the "Official Scout" car might be the yellow “ammunition wagon” described in the Washington Post of Feb 13 as driven by Miss Elizabeth Freeman, the “official orator.” But apparently it was really a wagon, as captured in this other Bain photo. The driver of the car resembles Jessie Stubs, pictured here with General Jones, but should be Mrs. Richard Schultz (info below).

Okay, I found the spot! (sorry for the multiple posts, and the stream-of-conscious effect) This photo was taken on Broad Street, looking north, just north of West Kinney Street. In Newark, New Jersey. I matched the spire to this photo captioned 950 Broad on newarkstreets.com. The City of Newark landmarks page for visitors indicates that this is Grace Episcopal Church - here's a photo of Grace on Flickr. The dome behind Grace is identified by newarkstreets.com as 920 Broad. On the Newark landmark page, this ends up being the Newark City Hall itself. A photo of the city hall from Flickr. Here's a bird's eye map of the scene, the angle isn't quite right. (** this sentence isn't quite right, see below) The tall building in the background on the right hand side should be at Market Street. Since this is Newark, this is February 12, 1913. They were in Elizabeth soon after noon, so this maybe 10:30am.

This is probably February 1913. A group of women walked from Newark, NJ to join the Suffrage Pageant and Procession on March 3, 1914 before Woodrow Wilson Inauguration. See article about Craft and Jones getting angry with each other in New York Times (the NY Times made fun of the entire Pageant and Procession, so the tone is not surprising): http://query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=1&res=9807E3D61E3AE633A25756C2A9649C946296D6CF

The Women's Suffrage Pilgrimage from New York City to Washington, D.C., was timed to arrive in the capital on March 3, 1913 -- the day before the inauguration of U. S. President Woodrow Wilson. The ladies (and gentleman supporters) managed to leverage a good dose of publicity from all the attention focused on inaugural events.

George H. Kendall was the president of the New York Bank Note Company, which amongst other things, printed stock certificates. That matter was the root of a long running dispute with the NYSE. From the New York Times of March 10, 1913 : "The fight between the exchange and Mr. Kendall is an old one. He said at the hearing it had been going on for thirty-four years. He has sued the exchange and its members and the case is pending in the United States District Court. From time to time he has exhibited on his building inlower sixth avenue enormous painted signs denouncing the "thieves of the New York Stock Exchange." Some of the signs are in place at the present time. " (ref. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9903E2D9103CE633A... ) See a raft of New York Times stories on the dispute here: query.nytimes.com/search/sitesearch?query=George+H.+endal...

Some searching in the NYT reveals that Friedmann was in the country from March through June 1913 and in the news frequently The turtle vaccine, Friedmann's intent to patent it , and his ethics were clearly controversial and the vaccine was banned by the New York Health Board on May 29, 1913 according to the NYT the next day. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9C02E0DB143FE633A... The date on the stamp is March 24(?) 1913. An article on March 25, 1913 suggests he visited several hospitals that day: Hospital for Deformities and Diseased Joints (where the crowds to see him were noted), Mount Sinai, and Montefiore Home, query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9C0CE5DD1F3AE633A... FRIEDMANN PATIENT DIES IN BELLEVUE; Prof. Ostrander, Treated on Friday, Expires from Tuberculosis of the Lungs and Kidneys.

This is Lyndhurst, a Gothic Revival mansion begun in 1838 and expanded in 1864-65. Alexander Jackson Davis was the architect. Financier Jay Gould bought it as a summer home in 1880. After his death it became the home of his eldest daughter, Helen, and, on Helen's death, his younger daughter Anna took charge of the property. Anna left Lyndhurst to the National Trust for Historic Preservation on her death in 1961. Today it is a museum. Lyndhurst web site. Edit: The web site New York Social Diary provides this extensive page featuring many modern photographs of Lyndhurst and its grounds.

The Florence Griswold house, in Old Lyme, Connecticut, was built in 1817. It was designed by architect Samuel Belcher, in what is now called the the Late Georgian style (in England), or the Federal style (in the United States.) In 1841, it became the home of sea captain Robert Griswold. In the late 19th century, Captain Griswold's heirs, including his daughter Florence (1850-1937), began taking in boarders. Among these boarders were several artists, and by the 1910s, the Griswold boarding house, and its proprietor, had become the center of Old Lyme's thriving artist colony. The Griswold house has been the Florence Griswold Museum since 1947. It was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1975, and was declared a national historic Landmark in 1993. Florence Griswold Museum web site.

May be the USS McClellan, which was in service during WWI.
Private Chester W. Ballard served with the Butchery Co. #307 in France on the USS McClellan, a troop ship which had been converted into a refrigerator ship, where fresh meat for the army could be stored and frozen before going to the battle front. Butchery Co. #307 consisted of 57 selected men, 1 officer, 20 noncommissioned officers and 36 Privates nearly all of which were in some way experienced in storing, freezing and shipping meats.
www.wwvets.com/WW1_Infantry.asp
The writing on the ship's side appears to say "US Army Transport/McClellan" but it pixelates and I can't be sure.

Slack13: thanks for the research on the McClellan. The ship appears to be the US Army Transport McClellan, purchased by the Army in 1898 and used until it was sold in 1919. See information from the Naval Historical Center: www.history.navy.mil/photos/sh-us-cs/army-sh/usash-mr/mcc...

Looks like there's a date of 2/22/13 written on the back of this photo, which would mean it was taken a few days before Woodrow Wilson's inauguration on March 3, 1913.
slack13:  Thanks for catching the date.  We will update the information and reload the description.

Some photos appear to be part of a series numbered 2646-1 thru at least 2646-15. Lincoln's pew is 2646-10, Inaug platform -11, Capitol showing platform -12, Stand in front of Treasury -13, Pres'l viewing stand -15. Several of these are dated 2/22/13, as noted by others. Oddly, 2646-1 thru 2646-6 are dated later, 5/3/13. These include Suffragette parade-1, Madge Udall -5, Inez Holland -6. The numbering system evidently is not chronological--probably thematic.
There is a "2/22/13" written backward on the right side, so it looks like it goes with the other shots from the Wilson inauguration.
